tables.name: aws.aws_cost_by_service_usage_type_monthly
tables.comment: AWS Cost Explorer - Cost by Service and Usage Type (Monthly)

columns.name: service
columns.comment: The name of the AWS service.

columns.name: usage_type
columns.comment: The usage type of this metric.

columns.name: period_start
columns.comment: Start timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: period_end
columns.comment: End timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: estimated
columns.comment: Whether the result is estimated.

columns.name: blended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the average cost of usage across the consolidated billing family. If you use the consolidated billing feature in AWS Organizations, you can view costs using blended rates.

columns.name: blended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for blended costs.

columns.name: unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: Unblended costs represent your usage costs on the day they are charged to you. In finance terms, they represent your costs on a cash basis of accounting.

columns.name: unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for unblended costs.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the unblended cost after discounts.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net unblended costs.

columns.name: amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the effective cost of the upfront and monthly reservation fees spread across the billing period. By default, Cost Explorer shows the fees for Reserved Instances as a spike on the day that you're charged, but if you choose to show costs as amortized costs, the costs are amortized over the billing period. This means that the costs are broken out into the effective daily rate. AWS estimates your amortized costs by combining your unblended costs with the amortized portion of your upfront and recurring reservation fees.

columns.name: amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for amortized costs.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric amortizes the upfront and monthly reservation fees while including discounts such as RI volume discounts.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net amortized costs.

columns.name: usage_quantity_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred. NOTE: If you return the UsageQuantity metric, the service aggregates all usage numbers without taking into account the units. For example, if you aggregate usageQuantity across all of Amazon EC2, the results aren't meaningful because Amazon EC2 compute hours and data transfer are measured in different units (for example, hours vs. GB).

columns.name: usage_quantity_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for usage quantity.

columns.name: normalized_usage_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred, in normalized units, for size-flexible RIs. The NormalizedUsageAmount is equal to UsageAmount multiplied by NormalizationFactor.

columns.name: normalized_usage_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for normalized usage.

tables.comment: AWS RDS DB Instance Automated Backup

columns.name: db_instance_identifier
columns.comment: The friendly name to identify the DB Instance.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the replicated automated backups.

columns.name: db_instance_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the automated backups.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: Specifies the current state of this database.

columns.name: allocated_storage
columns.comment: Specifies the allocated storage size in gibibytes (GiB).

columns.name: availability_zone
columns.comment: The Availability Zone that the automated backup was created in.

columns.name: backup_retention_period
columns.comment: The retention period for the automated backups.

columns.name: backup_target
columns.comment: Specifies where automated backups are stored: Amazon Web Services Outposts or the Amazon Web Services Region.

columns.name: dbi_resource_id
columns.comment: The identifier for the source DB instance, which can't be changed and which is unique to an Amazon Web Services Region.

columns.name: encrypted
columns.comment: Specifies whether the automated backup is encrypted.

columns.name: engine
columns.comment: The name of the database engine for this automated backup.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: The version of the database engine for the automated backup.

columns.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
columns.comment: True if mapping of Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) accounts to database accounts is enabled, and otherwise false.

columns.name: instance_create_time
columns.comment: True if mapping of Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) accounts to database accounts is enabled, and otherwise false.

columns.name: iops
columns.comment: True if mapping of Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) accounts to database accounts is enabled, and otherwise false.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: The Amazon Web Services KMS key ID for an automated backup. The Amazon Web Services KMS key identifier is the key ARN, key ID, alias ARN, or alias name for the KMS key.

columns.name: license_model
columns.comment: The Amazon Web Services KMS key ID for an automated backup. The Amazon Web Services KMS key identifier is the key ARN, key ID, alias ARN, or alias name for the KMS key.

columns.name: master_username
columns.comment: The license model of an automated backup.

columns.name: option_group_name
columns.comment: The option group the automated backup is associated with. If omitted, the default option group for the engine specified is used.

columns.name: port
columns.comment: The port number that the automated backup used for connections. Default: Inherits from the source DB instance Valid Values: 1150-65535.

columns.name: storage_throughput
columns.comment: Specifies the storage throughput for the automated backup.

columns.name: storage_type
columns.comment: Specifies the storage type associated with the automated backup.

columns.name: tde_credential_arn
columns.comment: The ARN from the key store with which the automated backup is associated for TDE encryption.

columns.name: timezone
columns.comment: The time zone of the automated backup.

columns.name: vpc_id
columns.comment: Provides the VPC ID associated with the DB instance.

columns.name: db_instance_automated_backups_replications
columns.comment: The list of replications to different Amazon Web Services Regions associated with the automated backup.

columns.name: restore_window
columns.comment: Earliest and latest time an instance can be restored to.

columns.name: integration_id
columns.comment: Represents the identifier of an integration.

columns.name: api_id
columns.comment: Represents the identifier of an API.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) specifying the integration.

columns.name: description
columns.comment: Represents the description of an integration.

columns.name: integration_method
columns.comment: Specifies the integration's HTTP method type.

columns.name: integration_type
columns.comment: Represents an API method integration type.

columns.name: integration_uri
columns.comment: A string representation of a URI with a length between [1-2048]. For a Lambda integration, specify the URI of a Lambda function. For an HTTP integration, specify a fully-qualified URL.

columns.name: api_gateway_managed
columns.comment: Specifies whether an integration is managed by API Gateway. If you created an API using using quick create, the resulting integration is managed by API Gateway. You can update a managed integration, but you can't delete it.

columns.name: connection_id
columns.comment: The ID of the VPC link for a private integration. Supported only for HTTP APIs.

columns.name: connection_type
columns.comment: Represents a connection type.

columns.name: content_handling_strategy
columns.comment: Specifies how to handle response payload content type conversions. Supported only for WebSocket APIs.

columns.name: credentials_arn
columns.comment: Specifies the credentials required for the integration, if any. For AWS integrations, three options are available. To specify an IAM Role for API Gateway to assume, use the role's Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

columns.name: integration_response_selection_expression
columns.comment: An expression used to extract information at runtime. See Selection Expressions(https://docs.aws.amazon.com/apigateway/latest/developerguide/apigateway-websocket-api-selection-expressions.html#apigateway-websocket-api-apikey-selection-expressions for more information.

columns.name: integration_subtype
columns.comment: A string with a length between [1-128].

columns.name: passthrough_behavior
columns.comment: Represents passthrough behavior for an integration response. Supported only for WebSocket APIs.

columns.name: payload_format_version
columns.comment: Specifies the format of the payload sent to an integration. Required for HTTP APIs.

columns.name: template_selection_expression
columns.comment: The template selection expression for the integration. Supported only for WebSocket APIs.

columns.name: timeout_in_millis
columns.comment: Indicates custom timeout between 50 and 29,000 milliseconds for WebSocket APIs and between 50 and 30,000 milliseconds for HTTP APIs. The default timeout is 29 seconds for WebSocket APIs and 30 seconds for HTTP APIs.

columns.name: request_parameters
columns.comment: For HTTP API itegrations, without a specified integrationSubtype request parameters are a key-value map specifying how to transform HTTP requests before sending them to backend integrations. The key should follow the pattern <action>:<header|querystring|path>.<location>. The action can be append, overwrite or remove. For values, you can provide static values, or map request data, stage variables, or context variables that are evaluated at runtime. To learn more, see Transforming API requests and responses (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/apigateway/latest/developerguide/http-api-parameter-mapping.html).

columns.name: request_templates
columns.comment: Represents a map of Velocity templates that are applied on the request payload based on the value of the Content-Type header sent by the client. The content type value is the key in this map, and the template (as a String) is the value. Supported only for WebSocket APIs.

columns.name: response_parameters
columns.comment: API requests and responses (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/apigateway/latest/developerguide/http-api-parameter-mapping.html).

columns.name: tls_config
columns.comment: The TLS configuration for a private integration. If you specify a TLS configuration, private integration traffic uses the HTTPS protocol. Supported only for HTTP APIs.

tables.name: aws.aws_cost_by_service_usage_type_daily
tables.comment: AWS Cost Explorer - Cost by Service and Usage Type (Daily)

columns.name: service
columns.comment: The name of the AWS service.

columns.name: usage_type
columns.comment: The usage type of this metric.

columns.name: period_start
columns.comment: Start timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: period_end
columns.comment: End timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: estimated
columns.comment: Whether the result is estimated.

columns.name: blended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the average cost of usage across the consolidated billing family. If you use the consolidated billing feature in AWS Organizations, you can view costs using blended rates.

columns.name: blended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for blended costs.

columns.name: unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: Unblended costs represent your usage costs on the day they are charged to you. In finance terms, they represent your costs on a cash basis of accounting.

columns.name: unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for unblended costs.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the unblended cost after discounts.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net unblended costs.

columns.name: amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the effective cost of the upfront and monthly reservation fees spread across the billing period. By default, Cost Explorer shows the fees for Reserved Instances as a spike on the day that you're charged, but if you choose to show costs as amortized costs, the costs are amortized over the billing period. This means that the costs are broken out into the effective daily rate. AWS estimates your amortized costs by combining your unblended costs with the amortized portion of your upfront and recurring reservation fees.

columns.name: amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for amortized costs.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric amortizes the upfront and monthly reservation fees while including discounts such as RI volume discounts.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net amortized costs.

columns.name: usage_quantity_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred. NOTE: If you return the UsageQuantity metric, the service aggregates all usage numbers without taking into account the units. For example, if you aggregate usageQuantity across all of Amazon EC2, the results aren't meaningful because Amazon EC2 compute hours and data transfer are measured in different units (for example, hours vs. GB).

columns.name: usage_quantity_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for usage quantity.

columns.name: normalized_usage_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred, in normalized units, for size-flexible RIs. The NormalizedUsageAmount is equal to UsageAmount multiplied by NormalizationFactor.

columns.name: normalized_usage_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for normalized usage.

columns.comment: Specifies the number of days for which automatic snapshots are retained.

columns.comment: The identifier of the CA certificate for this DB instance.

columns.name: copy_tags_to_snapshot
columns.comment: Specifies whether tags are copied from the DB instance to snapshots of the DB instance, or not.

columns.comment: Specifies the ID that Amazon Route 53 assigns when you create a hosted zone.

columns.name: endpoint_port
columns.comment: Specifies the port that the database engine is listening on.

columns.name: engine
columns.comment: The name of the database engine to be used for this instance.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: Indicates the database engine version.

columns.name: instance_create_time

columns.name: kms_key_id

columns.name: latest_restorable_time

columns.name: preferred_backup_window

columns.name: preferred_maintenance_window
columns.comment: Specifies the weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur.

columns.name: promotion_tier
columns.comment: A value that specifies the order in which an Amazon DocumentDB replica is promoted to the primary instance after a failure of the existing primary instance.

columns.name: publicly_accessible

columns.name: storage_encrypted

columns.name: vpc_id

columns.comment: The unique identifier for the service-specific credential.

columns.name: create_date
columns.comment: The date and time, in ISO 8601 date-time format (http://www.iso.org/iso/iso8601), when the service-specific credential were created.

columns.name: service_user_name
columns.comment: The generated user name for the service-specific credential.

columns.comment: The status of the service-specific credential. Active means that the key is valid for API calls, while Inactive means it is not.

columns.name: user_name
columns.comment: The name of the IAM user associated with the service-specific credential.

columns.comment: The creation date and time for the launch configuration.

columns.comment: The ID of the Amazon Machine Image (AMI) to use to launch EC2 instances.

columns.name: instance_type
columns.comment: The instance type for the instances.

columns.name: associate_public_ip_address
columns.comment: For Auto Scaling groups that are running in a VPC, specifies whether to assign a public IP address to the group's instances.

columns.name: kernel_id
columns.comment: The ID of the kernel associated with the AMI.

columns.name: key_name
columns.comment: The name of the key pair to be associated with instances.

columns.name: ramdisk_id
columns.comment: The ID of the RAM disk associated with the AMI.

columns.name: ebs_optimized
columns.comment: Specifies whether the launch configuration is optimized for EBS I/O (true) or not (false).

columns.name: classic_link_vpc_id
columns.comment: The ID of a ClassicLink-enabled VPC to link EC2-Classic instances to.

columns.name: spot_price
columns.comment: The maximum hourly price to be paid for any Spot Instance launched to fulfill the request. Spot Instances are launched when the price you specified exceeds the current Spot price.

columns.name: user_data
columns.comment: The Base64-encoded user data to make available to the launched EC2 instances.

columns.name: placement_tenancy
columns.comment: The tenancy of the instance, either default or dedicated. An instance with dedicated tenancy runs on isolated, single-tenant hardware and can only be launched into a VPC.

columns.name: iam_instance_profile
columns.comment: The name or the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance profile associated with the IAM role for the instance.

columns.name: instance_monitoring_enabled
columns.comment: Describes whether detailed monitoring is enabled for the Auto Scaling instances.

columns.name: metadata_options_http_endpoint
columns.comment: This parameter enables or disables the HTTP metadata endpoint on instances. If the parameter is not specified, the default state is enabled.

columns.name: metadata_options_put_response_hop_limit
columns.comment: The desired HTTP PUT response hop limit for instance metadata requests. The larger the number, the further instance metadata requests can travel.

columns.name: metadata_options_http_tokens
columns.comment: The state of token usage for your instance metadata requests. If the parameter is not specified in the request, the default state is optional.

columns.name: block_device_mappings
columns.comment: A block device mapping, which specifies the block devices for the instance.

columns.name: classic_link_vpc_security_groups
columns.comment: The IDs of one or more security groups for the VPC specified in ClassicLinkVPCId.

columns.name: security_groups
columns.comment: A list that contains the security groups to assign to the instances in the Auto Scaling group.

columns.comment: The name of the metric.

columns.name: namespace
columns.comment: The metric namespace.

columns.name: average
columns.comment: The average of the metric values that correspond to the data point.

columns.name: maximum
columns.comment: The maximum metric value for the data point.

columns.name: minimum
columns.comment: The minimum metric value for the data point.

columns.name: sample_count
columns.comment: The number of metric values that contributed to the aggregate value of this data point.

columns.name: sum
columns.comment: The sum of the metric values for the data point.

columns.name: unit
columns.comment: The standard unit for the data point.

columns.name: timestamp
columns.comment: The time stamp used for the data point.

columns.name: id
columns.comment: The identifier for the Distribution.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The ARN (Amazon Resource Name) for the distribution.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: The current status of the Distribution.

columns.name: caller_reference
columns.comment: A unique value that ensures that the request can't be replayed.

columns.name: comment
columns.comment: The comment originally specified when this Distribution was created.

columns.name: default_root_object
columns.comment: The object that you want CloudFront to request from your origin.

columns.name: domain_name
columns.comment: The domain name that corresponds to the Distribution.

columns.name: enabled
columns.comment: Whether the Distribution is enabled to accept user requests for content.

columns.name: e_tag
columns.comment: The current version of the configuration.

columns.name: http_version
columns.comment: Specify the maximum HTTP version that you want viewers to use to communicate with CloudFront. The default value for new web Distributions is http2. Viewers that don't support HTTP/2 will automatically use an earlier version.

columns.name: is_ipv6_enabled
columns.comment: Whether CloudFront responds to IPv6 DNS requests with an IPv6 address for your Distribution.

columns.name: in_progress_invalidation_batches
columns.comment: The number of invalidation batches currently in progress.

columns.name: last_modified_time
columns.comment: The date and time the Distribution was last modified.

columns.name: price_class
columns.comment: A complex type that contains information about price class for this streaming Distribution.

columns.name: web_acl_id
columns.comment: The Web ACL Id (if any) associated with the distribution.

columns.name: active_trusted_key_groups
columns.comment: CloudFront automatically adds this field to the response if youve configured a cache behavior in this distribution to serve private content using key groups.

columns.name: active_trusted_signers
columns.comment: A list of AWS accounts and the identifiers of active CloudFront key pairs in each account that CloudFront can use to verify the signatures of signed URLs and signed cookies.

columns.name: aliases
columns.comment: A complex type that contains information about CNAMEs (alternate domain names),if any, for this distribution.

columns.name: alias_icp_recordals
columns.comment: AWS services in China customers must file for an Internet Content Provider (ICP) recordal if they want to serve content publicly on an alternate domain name, also known as a CNAME, that they've added to CloudFront. AliasICPRecordal provides the ICP recordal status for CNAMEs associated with distributions.

columns.name: cache_behaviors
columns.comment: The number of cache behaviors for this Distribution.

columns.name: custom_error_responses
columns.comment: A complex type that contains zero or more CustomErrorResponses elements.

columns.name: default_cache_behavior
columns.comment: A complex type that describes the default cache behavior if you don't specify a CacheBehavior element or if files don't match any of the values of PathPattern in CacheBehavior elements. You must create exactly one default cache behavior.

columns.name: logging
columns.comment: A complex type that controls whether access logs are written for the distribution.

columns.name: origins
columns.comment: A complex type that contains information about origins for this distribution.

columns.name: origin_groups
columns.comment: A complex type that contains information about origin groups for this distribution.

columns.name: restrictions
columns.comment: A complex type that identifies ways in which you want to restrict distribution of your content.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to the Maintenance Window

columns.name: viewer_certificate
columns.comment: A complex type that determines the distribution's SSL/TLS configuration for communicating with viewers.

columns.comment: Reserved. If you need to sustain traffic greater than the documented limits (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/vpc-nat-gateway.html).

tables.name: aws.aws_cost_by_service_monthly
tables.comment: AWS Cost Explorer - Cost by Service (Monthly)

columns.name: service
columns.comment: The name of the AWS service.

columns.name: period_start
columns.comment: Start timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: period_end
columns.comment: End timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: estimated
columns.comment: Whether the result is estimated.

columns.name: blended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the average cost of usage across the consolidated billing family. If you use the consolidated billing feature in AWS Organizations, you can view costs using blended rates.

columns.name: blended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for blended costs.

columns.name: unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: Unblended costs represent your usage costs on the day they are charged to you. In finance terms, they represent your costs on a cash basis of accounting.

columns.name: unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for unblended costs.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the unblended cost after discounts.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net unblended costs.

columns.name: amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the effective cost of the upfront and monthly reservation fees spread across the billing period. By default, Cost Explorer shows the fees for Reserved Instances as a spike on the day that you're charged, but if you choose to show costs as amortized costs, the costs are amortized over the billing period. This means that the costs are broken out into the effective daily rate. AWS estimates your amortized costs by combining your unblended costs with the amortized portion of your upfront and recurring reservation fees.

columns.name: amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for amortized costs.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric amortizes the upfront and monthly reservation fees while including discounts such as RI volume discounts.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net amortized costs.

columns.name: usage_quantity_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred. NOTE: If you return the UsageQuantity metric, the service aggregates all usage numbers without taking into account the units. For example, if you aggregate usageQuantity across all of Amazon EC2, the results aren't meaningful because Amazon EC2 compute hours and data transfer are measured in different units (for example, hours vs. GB).

columns.name: usage_quantity_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for usage quantity.

columns.name: normalized_usage_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred, in normalized units, for size-flexible RIs. The NormalizedUsageAmount is equal to UsageAmount multiplied by NormalizationFactor.

columns.name: normalized_usage_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for normalized usage.

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

columns.name: autoscaling_group_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Auto Scaling group.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: The current state of the group when the DeleteAutoScalingGroup operation is in progress.

columns.name: created_time
columns.comment: The date and time group was created.

columns.name: new_instances_protected_from_scale_in
columns.comment: Indicates whether newly launched instances are protected from termination by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling when scaling in.

columns.name: launch_configuration_name
columns.comment: The name of the associated launch configuration.

columns.name: default_cooldown
columns.comment: The duration of the default cooldown period, in seconds.

columns.name: desired_capacity
columns.comment: The desired size of the group.

columns.name: max_instance_lifetime
columns.comment: The maximum amount of time, in seconds, that an instance can be in service.

columns.name: max_size
columns.comment: The maximum size of the group.

columns.name: min_size
columns.comment: The minimum size of the group.

columns.name: health_check_grace_period
columns.comment: The amount of time, in seconds, that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling waits before checking the health status of an EC2 instance that has come into service.

columns.name: health_check_type
columns.comment: The service to use for the health checks. The valid values are EC2 and ELB. If you configure an Auto Scaling group to use ELB health checks, it considers the instance unhealthy if it fails either the EC2 status checks or the load balancer health checks.

columns.name: placement_group
columns.comment: The name of the placement group into which to launch your instances, if any.

columns.name: service_linked_role_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the service-linked role that the Auto Scaling group uses to call other AWS services on your behalf.

columns.name: vpc_zone_identifier
columns.comment: One or more subnet IDs, if applicable, separated by commas.

columns.name: launch_template_name
columns.comment: The launch template name for the group.

columns.name: launch_template_id
columns.comment: The ID of the launch template.

columns.name: launch_template_version
columns.comment: The version number, $Latest, or $Default.

columns.name: on_demand_allocation_strategy
columns.comment: Indicates how to allocate instance types to fulfill On-Demand capacity. The only valid value is prioritized, which is also the default value. This strategy uses the order of instance types in the overrides to define the launch priority of each instance type.

columns.name: on_demand_base_capacity
columns.comment: The minimum amount of the Auto Scaling group's capacity that must be fulfilled by On-Demand Instances. This base portion is provisioned first as group scales. Defaults to 0 if not specified.

columns.name: on_demand_percentage_above_base_capacity
columns.comment: Controls the percentages of On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances for your additional capacity beyond OnDemandBaseCapacity. Expressed as a number (for example, 20 specifies 20% On-Demand Instances, 80% Spot Instances). Defaults to 100 if not specified. If set to 100, only On-Demand Instances are provisioned.

columns.name: spot_allocation_strategy
columns.comment: Indicates how to allocate instances across Spot Instance pools. If the allocation strategy is lowest-price, the Auto Scaling group launches instances using the Spot pools with the lowest price, and evenly allocates your instances across the number of Spot pools that you specify. If the allocation strategy is capacity-optimized, the Auto Scaling group launches instances using Spot pools that are optimally chosen based on the available Spot capacity. Defaults to lowest-price if not specified.

columns.name: spot_instance_pools
columns.comment: The number of Spot Instance pools across which to allocate your Spot Instances.

columns.name: spot_max_price
columns.comment: The maximum price per unit hour that user is willing to pay for a Spot Instance. If the value of this parameter is blank (which is the default), the maximum Spot price is set at the On-Demand price.

columns.name: mixed_instances_policy_launch_template_name
columns.comment: The ID of the launch template for mixed instances policy.

columns.name: mixed_instances_policy_launch_template_id
columns.comment: The name of the launch template for mixed instances policy.

columns.name: mixed_instances_policy_launch_template_version
columns.comment: The version of the launch template for mixed instances policy.

columns.name: mixed_instances_policy_launch_template_overrides
columns.comment: Any parameters that is specified in the list override the same parameters in the launch template.

columns.name: availability_zones
columns.comment: One or more Availability Zones for the group.

columns.name: load_balancer_names
columns.comment: One or more load balancers associated with the group.

columns.name: target_group_arns
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Names (ARN) of the target groups for your load balancer.

columns.name: instances
columns.comment: The EC2 instances associated with the group.

columns.name: enabled_metrics
columns.comment: The metrics enabled for the group.

columns.name: policies
columns.comment: A set of scaling policies for the specified Auto Scaling group.

columns.name: termination_policies
columns.comment: The termination policies for the group.

columns.name: suspended_processes
columns.comment: The suspended processes associated with the group.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to the Auto Scaling Group.

columns.comment: A map of tags for the resource.

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the fleet.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the fleet.

columns.name: instance_type
columns.comment: The instance type to use when launching fleet instances.

columns.name: state
columns.comment: The current state for the fleet.

columns.name: created_time
columns.comment: The time the fleet was created.

columns.name: description
columns.comment: The description to display.

columns.name: display_name
columns.comment: The fleet name to display.

columns.name: disconnect_timeout_in_seconds
columns.comment: The amount of time that a streaming session remains active after users disconnect. If they try to reconnect to the streaming session after a disconnection or network interruption within this time interval, they are connected to their previous session. Otherwise, they are connected to a new session with a new streaming instance. Specify a value between 60 and 360000.

columns.name: directory_name
columns.comment: The fully qualified name of the directory (for example, corp.example.com).

columns.name: organizational_unit_distinguished_name
columns.comment: The distinguished name of the organizational unit for computer accounts.

columns.name: enable_default_internet_access
columns.comment: Indicates whether default internet access is enabled for the fleet.

columns.name: fleet_type
columns.comment: The fleet type. ALWAYS_ON Provides users with instant-on access to their apps. You are charged for all running instances in your fleet, even if no users are streaming apps. ON_DEMAND Provide users with access to applications after they connect, which takes one to two minutes. You are charged for instance streaming when users are connected and a small hourly fee for instances that are not streaming apps.

columns.name: iam_role_arn
columns.comment: The ARN of the IAM role that is applied to the fleet.

columns.name: idle_disconnect_timeout_in_seconds
columns.comment: The amount of time that users can be idle (inactive) before they are disconnected from their streaming session and the DisconnectTimeoutInSeconds time interval begins.

columns.name: image_arn
columns.comment: The ARN for the public, private, or shared image.

columns.name: image_name
columns.comment: The name of the image used to create the fleet.

columns.name: max_concurrent_sessions
columns.comment: The maximum number of concurrent sessions for the fleet.

columns.name: max_user_duration_in_seconds

columns.name: enable_execute_command
columns.comment: Whether or not execute command functionality is enabled for this task. If true, this enables execute command functionality on all containers in the task.

columns.name: execution_stopped_at

columns.name: group
columns.comment: The name of the task group associated with the task.

columns.name: health_status
columns.comment: The health status for the task, which is determined by the health of the essential containers in the task. If all essential containers in the task are reporting as HEALTHY, then the task status also reports as HEALTHY.

columns.name: last_status

columns.name: memory
columns.comment: The amount of memory (in MiB) used by the task as expressed in a task definition.

columns.name: platform_version

columns.name: pull_started_at
columns.comment: The Unix timestamp for when the container image pull began.

columns.name: pull_stopped_at

columns.name: version

columns.name: attachments

columns.name: attributes

columns.name: ephemeral_storage
columns.comment: The ephemeral storage settings for the task.

Subscribers can consume data by directly querying Lake Formation tables in your S3 bucket via services like Amazon Athena. This subscription type is defined as LAKEFORMATION.

columns.name: cluster_identifier
columns.comment: The unique identifier of the cluster.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) specifying the cluster.

columns.name: cluster_namespace_arn
columns.comment: The namespace Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster.

columns.name: allow_version_upgrade
columns.comment: A boolean value that, if true, indicates that major version upgrades will be applied automatically to the cluster during the maintenance window.

columns.name: automated_snapshot_retention_period
columns.comment: The number of days that automatic cluster snapshots are retained.

columns.name: availability_zone
columns.comment: The name of the Availability Zone in which the cluster is located.

columns.name: availability_zone_relocation_status
columns.comment: Describes the status of the Availability Zone relocation operation.

columns.name: cluster_availability_status
columns.comment: The availability status of the cluster for queries.

columns.name: cluster_create_time
columns.comment: The date and time that the cluster was created.

columns.name: cluster_nodes
columns.comment: The nodes in the cluster.

columns.name: cluster_parameter_groups
columns.comment: The list of cluster parameter groups that are associated with this cluster. Each parameter group in the list is returned with its status.

columns.name: cluster_public_key
columns.comment: The public key for the cluster.

columns.name: cluster_revision_number
columns.comment: The specific revision number of the database in the cluster.

columns.name: cluster_security_groups
columns.comment: A list of cluster security group that are associated with the cluster. Each security group is represented by an element that contains ClusterSecurityGroup.Name and ClusterSecurityGroup.Status subelements. Cluster security groups are used when the cluster is not created in an Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). Clusters that are created in a VPC use VPC security groups, which are listed by the VpcSecurityGroups parameter.

columns.name: cluster_snapshot_copy_status
columns.comment: A value that returns the destination region and retention period that are configured for cross-region snapshot copy.

columns.name: cluster_status
columns.comment: The current state of the cluster.

columns.name: cluster_subnet_group_name
columns.comment: The name of the subnet group that is associated with the cluster. This parameter is valid only when the cluster is in a VPC.

columns.name: cluster_version
columns.comment: The version ID of the Amazon Redshift engine that is running on the cluster.

columns.name: data_transfer_progress
columns.comment: Describes the status of a cluster while it is in the process of resizing with an incremental resize.

columns.name: db_name
columns.comment: The name of the initial database that was created when the cluster was created. This same name is returned for the life of the cluster. If an initial database was not specified, a database named devdev was created by default.

columns.name: deferred_maintenance_windows
columns.comment: Describes a group of DeferredMaintenanceWindow objects.

columns.name: elastic_ip_status
columns.comment: The status of the elastic IP (EIP) address.

columns.name: elastic_resize_number_of_node_options
columns.comment: The number of nodes that you can resize the cluster to with the elastic resize method.

columns.name: encrypted
columns.comment: A boolean value that, if true, indicates that data in the cluster is encrypted at rest.

columns.name: endpoint
columns.comment: The connection endpoint.

columns.name: enhanced_vpc_routing
columns.comment: An option that specifies whether to create the cluster with enhanced VPC routing enabled. To create a cluster that uses enhanced VPC routing, the cluster must be in a VPC. If this option is true, enhanced VPC routing is enabled.

columns.name: expected_next_snapshot_schedule_time
columns.comment: The date and time when the next snapshot is expected to be taken for clusters with a valid snapshot schedule and backups enabled.

columns.name: expected_next_snapshot_schedule_time_status
columns.comment: The status of next expected snapshot for clusters having a valid snapshot schedule and backups enabled.

columns.name: hsm_status
columns.comment: A value that reports whether the Amazon Redshift cluster has finished applying any hardware security module (HSM) settings changes specified in a modify cluster command.

columns.name: iam_roles
columns.comment: A list of AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles that can be used by the cluster to access other AWS services.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: The AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) key ID of the encryption key used to encrypt data in the cluster.

columns.name: maintenance_track_name
columns.comment: The name of the maintenance track for the cluster.

columns.name: manual_snapshot_retention_period
columns.comment: The default number of days to retain a manual snapshot. If the value is -1, the snapshot is retained indefinitely. This setting doesn't change the retention period of existing snapshots. The value must be either -1 or an integer between 1 and 3,653.

columns.name: master_username
columns.comment: The master user name for the cluster. This name is used to connect to the database that is specified in the DBName parameter.

columns.name: modify_status
columns.comment: The status of a modify operation, if any, initiated for the cluster.

columns.name: next_maintenance_window_start_time
columns.comment: The date and time in UTC when system maintenance can begin.

columns.name: node_type
columns.comment: The node type for the nodes in the cluster.

columns.name: number_of_nodes
columns.comment: The number of compute nodes in the cluster.

columns.name: pending_actions
columns.comment: Cluster operations that are waiting to be started.

columns.name: pending_modified_values
columns.comment: A value that, if present, indicates that changes to the cluster are pending. Specific pending changes are identified by subelements.

columns.name: preferred_maintenance_window
columns.comment: The weekly time range, in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC), during which system maintenance can occur.

columns.name: publicly_accessible
columns.comment: A boolean value that, if true, indicates that the cluster can be accessed from a public network.

columns.name: resize_info
columns.comment: Describes a resize operation.

columns.name: restore_status
columns.comment: A value that describes the status of a cluster restore action. This parameter returns null if the cluster was not created by restoring a snapshot.

columns.name: snapshot_schedule_identifier
columns.comment: A unique identifier for the cluster snapshot schedule.

columns.name: snapshot_schedule_state
columns.comment: The current state of the cluster snapshot schedule.

columns.name: vpc_id
columns.comment: The identifier of the VPC the cluster is in, if the cluster is in a VPC.

columns.name: vpc_security_groups
columns.comment: A list of Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC) security groups that are associated with the cluster. This parameter is returned only if the cluster is in a VPC.

columns.name: logging_status
columns.comment: Describes the status of logging for a cluster.

columns.name: scheduled_actions
columns.comment: A list of scheduled actions for specified cluster.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: The list of tags for the cluster.

columns.comment: The Amazon EC2 instance ID for the instance. When the AWS_EC2_INSTANCE_ID attribute is specified, then the AWS_INSTANCE_IPV4 attribute contains the primary private IPv4 address.

columns.name: alias_dns_name
columns.comment: For an alias record that routes traffic to an Elastic Load Balancing load balancer, the DNS name that's associated with the load balancer.

columns.name: instance_cname
columns.comment: A CNAME record, the domain name that Route 53 returns in response to DNS queries (for example, example.com ).

columns.name: init_health_status
columns.comment: If the service configuration includes HealthCheckCustomConfig, you can optionally use AWS_INIT_HEALTH_STATUS to specify the initial status of the custom health check, HEALTHY or UNHEALTHY. If you don't specify a value for AWS_INIT_HEALTH_STATUS, the initial status is HEALTHY.

columns.name: instance_ipv4

columns.name: instance_ipv6
columns.comment: For an AAAA record, the IPv6 address that Route 53 returns in response to DNS queries.

columns.name: instance_port
columns.comment: For an SRV record, the value that Route 53 returns for the port. In addition, if the service includes HealthCheckConfig, the port on the endpoint that Route 53 sends requests to.

columns.name: db_cluster_identifier
columns.comment: Contains a user-supplied DB cluster identifier. This identifier is the unique key that identifies a DB cluster.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the DB cluster.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: Specifies the current state of this DB cluster.

columns.name: cluster_create_time
columns.comment: Specifies the time when the DB cluster was created, in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC).

columns.name: allocated_storage
columns.comment: AllocatedStorage always returns 1, because Neptune DB cluster storage size is not fixed, but instead automatically adjusts as needed.

columns.name: automatic_restart_time
columns.comment: Time at which the DB cluster will be automatically restarted.

columns.name: backup_retention_period
columns.comment: Specifies the number of days for which automatic DB snapshots are retained.

columns.name: clone_group_id
columns.comment: Identifies the clone group to which the DB cluster is associated.

columns.name: copy_tags_to_snapshot
columns.comment: If set to true, tags are copied to any snapshot of the DB cluster that is created.

columns.name: cross_account_clone
columns.comment: If set to true, the DB cluster can be cloned across accounts.

columns.name: db_cluster_parameter_group
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the DB cluster parameter group for the DB cluster.

columns.name: db_subnet_group
columns.comment: Specifies information on the subnet group associated with the DB cluster.

columns.name: database_name
columns.comment: Contains the name of the initial database of this DB cluster that was provided.

columns.name: db_cluster_resource_id
columns.comment: The Amazon Region-unique, immutable identifier for the DB cluster.

columns.name: deletion_protection
columns.comment: Indicates whether or not the DB cluster has deletion protection enabled.

columns.name: earliest_restorable_time
columns.comment: Specifies the earliest time to which a database can be restored with point-in-time restore.

columns.name: endpoint
columns.comment: Specifies the connection endpoint for the primary instance of the DB cluster.

columns.name: engine
columns.comment: Provides the name of the database engine to be used for this DB cluster.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: Indicates the database engine version.

columns.name: hosted_zone_id
columns.comment: Specifies the ID that Amazon Route 53 assigns when you create a hosted zone.

columns.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
columns.comment: True if mapping of Amazon Identity and Access Management (IAM) accounts to database accounts is enabled, and otherwise false.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: If StorageEncrypted is true, the Amazon KMS key identifier for the encrypted DB cluster.

columns.name: latest_restorable_time
columns.comment: Specifies the latest time to which a database can be restored with point-in-time restore.

columns.name: multi_az
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB cluster has instances in multiple Availability Zones.

columns.name: percent_progress
columns.comment: Specifies the progress of the operation as a percentage.

columns.name: port
columns.comment: Specifies the port that the database engine is listening on.

columns.name: preferred_backup_window
columns.comment: Specifies the daily time range during which automated backups are created if automated backups are enabled, as determined by the BackupRetentionPeriod.

columns.name: preferred_maintenance_window
columns.comment: Specifies the weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur, in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC).

columns.name: reader_endpoint
columns.comment: The reader endpoint for the DB cluster.

columns.name: storage_encrypted
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB cluster is encrypted.

columns.name: associated_roles
columns.comment: Provides a list of the Amazon Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles.

columns.name: availability_zones
columns.comment: Provides the list of EC2 Availability Zones that instances in the DB cluster can be created in.

columns.name: db_cluster_members
columns.comment: Provides the list of instances that make up the DB cluster.

columns.name: enabled_cloudwatch_logs_exports
columns.comment: A list of log types that this DB cluster is configured to export to CloudWatch Logs.

columns.name: read_replica_identifiers
columns.comment: Contains one or more identifiers of the Read Replicas associated with this DB cluster.

columns.name: vpc_security_groups
columns.comment: Provides a list of VPC security groups that the DB cluster belongs to.

columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to the resource.

tables.name: aws.aws_cost_by_account_monthly
tables.comment: AWS Cost Explorer - Cost by Linked Account (Monthly)

columns.name: linked_account_id
columns.comment: The AWS Account ID.

columns.name: period_start
columns.comment: Start timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: period_end
columns.comment: End timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: estimated
columns.comment: Whether the result is estimated.

columns.name: blended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the average cost of usage across the consolidated billing family. If you use the consolidated billing feature in AWS Organizations, you can view costs using blended rates.

columns.name: blended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for blended costs.

columns.name: unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: Unblended costs represent your usage costs on the day they are charged to you. In finance terms, they represent your costs on a cash basis of accounting.

columns.name: unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for unblended costs.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the unblended cost after discounts.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net unblended costs.

columns.name: amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the effective cost of the upfront and monthly reservation fees spread across the billing period. By default, Cost Explorer shows the fees for Reserved Instances as a spike on the day that you're charged, but if you choose to show costs as amortized costs, the costs are amortized over the billing period. This means that the costs are broken out into the effective daily rate. AWS estimates your amortized costs by combining your unblended costs with the amortized portion of your upfront and recurring reservation fees.

columns.name: amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for amortized costs.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric amortizes the upfront and monthly reservation fees while including discounts such as RI volume discounts.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net amortized costs.

columns.name: usage_quantity_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred. NOTE: If you return the UsageQuantity metric, the service aggregates all usage numbers without taking into account the units. For example, if you aggregate usageQuantity across all of Amazon EC2, the results aren't meaningful because Amazon EC2 compute hours and data transfer are measured in different units (for example, hours vs. GB).

columns.name: usage_quantity_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for usage quantity.

columns.name: normalized_usage_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred, in normalized units, for size-flexible RIs. The NormalizedUsageAmount is equal to UsageAmount multiplied by NormalizationFactor.

columns.name: normalized_usage_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for normalized usage.

columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the rule group.

columns.name: capacity
columns.comment: The maximum operating resources that this rule group can use. Rule group capacity is fixed at creation. When you update a rule group, you are limited to this capacity. When you reference a rule group from a firewall policy, Network Firewall reserves this capacity for the rule group.

columns.name: consumed_capacity
columns.comment: The number of capacity units currently consumed by the rule group rules.

columns.name: description
columns.comment: A description of the rule group.

columns.name: number_of_associations
columns.comment: The number of firewall policies that use this rule group.

columns.name: rule_group_id
columns.comment: The unique identifier for the rule group.

columns.name: rule_group_status
columns.comment: Detailed information about the current status of a rule group.

columns.name: rule_variables
columns.comment: Settings that are available for use in the rules in the rule group. You can only use these for stateful rule groups.

columns.name: rules_source
columns.comment: The stateful rules or stateless rules for the rule group.

columns.name: stateful_rule_options
columns.comment: Additional options governing how Network Firewall handles the rule group. You can only use these for stateful rule groups.

columns.name: type
columns.comment: Indicates whether the rule group is stateless or stateful. If the rule group is stateless, it contains stateless rules. If it is stateful, it contains stateful rules.

tables.name: aws.aws_s3_object
tables.comment: List AWS S3 Objects in S3 buckets by bucket name.

columns.name: key
columns.comment: The name that you assign to an object. You use the object key to retrieve the object.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The ARN of the AWS S3 Object.

columns.name: bucket_name
columns.comment: The name of the container bucket of this object.

columns.name: last_modified
columns.comment: Last modified time of the object.

columns.name: storage_class
columns.comment: The class of storage used to store the object.

columns.name: version_id
columns.comment: The version ID of the object.

columns.name: accept_ranges
columns.comment: Indicates that a range of bytes was specified.

columns.name: body
columns.comment: The raw bytes of the object data as a string. If the bytes entirely consists of valid UTF8 runes, an UTF8 is sent otherwise the bas64 encoding of the bytes is sent.

columns.name: bucket_key_enabled
columns.comment: Indicates whether the object uses an S3 Bucket Key for server-side encryption with Amazon Web Services KMS (SSE-KMS)

columns.name: cache_control
columns.comment: Specifies caching behavior along the request/reply chain.

columns.name: checksum_crc32
columns.comment: The base64-encoded, 32-bit CRC32 checksum of the object. This will only be present if it was uploaded with the object. With multipart uploads, this may not be a checksum value of the object.

columns.name: checksum_crc32c
columns.comment: The base64-encoded, 32-bit CRC32C checksum of the object. This will only be present if it was uploaded with the object. With multipart uploads, this may not be a checksum value of the object.

columns.name: checksum_sha1
columns.comment: The base64-encoded, 160-bit SHA-1 digest of the object. This will only be present if it was uploaded with the object. With multipart uploads, this may not be a checksum value of the object.

columns.name: checksum_sha256
columns.comment: The base64-encoded, 256-bit SHA-256 digest of the object. This will only be present if it was uploaded with the object. With multipart uploads, this may not be a checksum value of the object.

columns.name: content_disposition
columns.comment: Specifies presentational information for the object.

columns.name: content_encoding
columns.comment: Specifies what content encodings have been applied to the object.

columns.name: content_language
columns.comment: The language the content is in.

columns.name: content_length
columns.comment: Size of the body in bytes.

columns.name: content_range
columns.comment: The portion of the object returned in the response.

columns.name: content_type
columns.comment: A standard MIME type describing the format of the object data.

columns.name: delete_marker
columns.comment: Specifies whether the object retrieved was (true) or was not (false) a delete marker.

columns.name: expiration
columns.comment: If the object expiration is configured (see PUT Bucket lifecycle), the response includes this header. It includes the expiry-date and rule-id key-value pairs providing object expiration information. The value of the rule-id is URL-encoded.

columns.name: expires
columns.comment: The date and time at which the object is no longer cacheable.

columns.name: etag
columns.comment: The entity tag of the object.

columns.name: object_lock_legal_hold_status
columns.comment: Like a retention period, a legal hold prevents an object version from being overwritten or deleted. A legal hold remains in effect until removed.

columns.name: object_lock_mode
columns.comment: The Object Lock mode currently in place for this object.

columns.name: object_lock_retain_until_date
columns.comment: The date and time when this object's Object Lock will expire.

columns.name: parts_count
columns.comment: The count of parts this object has. This value is only returned if you specify partNumber in your request and the object was uploaded as a multipart upload.

columns.name: prefix
columns.comment: The prefix of the key of the object.

columns.name: replication_status
columns.comment: Amazon S3 can return this if your request involves a bucket that is either a source or destination in a replication rule.

columns.name: request_charged
columns.comment: If present, indicates that the requester was successfully charged for the request.

columns.name: restore
columns.comment: Provides information about object restoration action and expiration time of the restored object copy.

columns.name: server_side_encryption
columns.comment: The server-side encryption algorithm used when storing this object in Amazon S3.

columns.name: size
columns.comment: Size in bytes of the object.

columns.name: sse_customer_algorithm
columns.comment: If server-side encryption with a customer-provided encryption key was requested, the response will include this header confirming the encryption algorithm used.

columns.name: sse_customer_key_md5
columns.comment: If server-side encryption with a customer-provided encryption key was requested, the response will include this header to provide round-trip message integrity verification of the customer-provided encryption key.

columns.name: sse_kms_key_id
columns.comment: If present, specifies the ID of the Amazon Web Services Key Management Service(Amazon Web Services KMS) symmetric customer managed key that was used for the object.

columns.name: tag_count
columns.comment: The number of tags, if any, on the object.

columns.name: website_redirection_location
columns.comment: If the bucket is configured as a website, redirects requests for this object  to another object in the same bucket or to an external URL.

columns.name: acl
columns.comment: ACLs define which AWS accounts or groups are granted access along with the type of access.

columns.name: checksum
columns.comment: The checksum or digest of the object.

columns.name: metadata
columns.comment: A map of metadata to store with the object in S3.

columns.name: object_parts
columns.comment: A collection of parts associated with a multipart upload.

columns.name: owner
columns.comment: The owner of the object.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to the object.

columns.name: tags
columns.comment: A map of tags for the resource.

columns.comment: Title of the resource.

columns.name: db_instance_identifier
columns.comment: The friendly name to identify the DB Instance.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the DB Instance.

columns.name: db_cluster_identifier
columns.comment: The friendly name to identify the DB cluster, that the DB instance is a member of.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: Specifies the current state of this database.

columns.name: class
columns.comment: Contains the name of the compute and memory capacity class of the DB instance.

columns.name: resource_id
columns.comment: The AWS Region-unique, immutable identifier for the DB instance.

columns.name: allocated_storage
columns.comment: Specifies the allocated storage size specified in gibibytes(GiB).

columns.name: auto_minor_version_upgrade
columns.comment: Specifies whether minor version patches are applied automatically, or not.

columns.name: availability_zone
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the Availability Zone the DB instance is located in.

columns.name: backup_retention_period
columns.comment: Specifies the number of days for which automatic DB snapshots are retained.

columns.name: ca_certificate_identifier
columns.comment: The identifier of the CA certificate for this DB instance.

columns.name: character_set_name
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the character set that this instance is associated with.

columns.name: copy_tags_to_snapshot
columns.comment: Specifies whether tags are copied from the DB instance to snapshots of the DB instance, or not.

columns.name: customer_owned_ip_enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether a customer-owned IP address (CoIP) is enabled for an RDS on Outposts DB instance, or not.

columns.name: port
columns.comment: Specifies the port that the DB instance listens on.

columns.name: db_name
columns.comment: Contains the name of the initial database of this instance that was provided at create time.

columns.name: db_subnet_group_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the DB subnet group.

columns.name: db_subnet_group_description
columns.comment: Provides the description of the DB subnet group.

columns.name: db_subnet_group_name
columns.comment: The name of the DB subnet group.

columns.name: db_subnet_group_status
columns.comment: Provides the status of the DB subnet group.

columns.name: deletion_protection
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB instance has deletion protection enabled, or not.

columns.name: endpoint_address
columns.comment: Specifies the DNS address of the DB instance.

columns.name: endpoint_hosted_zone_id
columns.comment: Specifies the ID that Amazon Route 53 assigns when you create a hosted zone.

columns.name: endpoint_port
columns.comment: Specifies the port that the database engine is listening on.

columns.name: engine
columns.comment: The name of the database engine to be used for this DB instance.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: Indicates the database engine version.

columns.name: enhanced_monitoring_resource_arn
columns.comment: The ARN of the Amazon CloudWatch Logs log stream that receives the Enhanced Monitoring metrics data for the DB instance.

columns.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether the the mapping of AWS IAM accounts to database accounts is enabled, or not.

columns.name: create_time
columns.comment: Provides the date and time the DB instance was created.

columns.name: iops
columns.comment: Specifies the Provisioned IOPS (I/O operations per second) value.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: The AWS KMS key identifier for the encrypted DB instance.

columns.name: latest_restorable_time
columns.comment: Specifies the latest time to which a database can be restored with point-in-time restore.

columns.name: license_model
columns.comment: License model information for this DB instance.

columns.name: master_user_name
columns.comment: Contains the master username for the DB instance.

columns.name: max_allocated_storage
columns.comment: The upper limit to which Amazon RDS can automatically scale the storage of the DB instance.

columns.name: monitoring_interval
columns.comment: The interval, in seconds, between points when Enhanced Monitoring metrics are collected for the DB instance.

columns.name: monitoring_role_arn
columns.comment: The ARN for the IAM role that permits RDS to send Enhanced Monitoring metrics to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

columns.name: multi_az
columns.comment: Specifies if the DB instance is a Multi-AZ deployment.

columns.name: nchar_character_set_name
columns.comment: The name of the NCHAR character set for the Oracle DB instance.

columns.name: performance_insights_enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether Performance Insights is enabled for the DB instance, or not.

columns.name: performance_insights_kms_key_id
columns.comment: The AWS KMS key identifier for encryption of Performance Insights data.

columns.name: performance_insights_retention_period
columns.comment: The amount of time, in days, to retain Performance Insights data.

columns.name: preferred_backup_window
columns.comment: Specifies the daily time range during which automated backups are created.

columns.name: preferred_maintenance_window
columns.comment: Specifies the weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur.

columns.name: promotion_tier
columns.comment: Specifies the order in which an Aurora Replica is promoted to the primary instance after a failure of the existing primary instance.

columns.name: publicly_accessible
columns.comment: Specifies the accessibility options for the DB instance.

columns.name: read_replica_source_db_instance_identifier
columns.comment: Contains the identifier of the source DB instance if this DB instance is a read replica.

columns.name: replica_mode
columns.comment: The mode of an Oracle read replica.

columns.name: secondary_availability_zone
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the secondary Availability Zone for a DB instance with multi-AZ support.

columns.name: storage_encrypted
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB instance is encrypted, or not.

columns.name: storage_throughput
columns.comment: Specifies the storage throughput for the DB instance. This setting applies only to the gp3 storage type.

columns.name: storage_type
columns.comment: Specifies the storage type associated with DB instance.

columns.name: tde_credential_arn
columns.comment: The ARN from the key store with which the instance is associated for TDE encryption.

columns.name: timezone
columns.comment: The time zone of the DB instance.

columns.name: vpc_id
columns.comment: Provides the VpcId of the DB subnet group.

columns.name: associated_roles
columns.comment: A list of AWS IAM roles that are associated with the DB instance.

columns.name: certificate
columns.comment: The CA certificate associated with the DB instance.

columns.name: db_parameter_groups
columns.comment: A list of DB parameter groups applied to this DB instance.

columns.name: db_security_groups
columns.comment: A list of DB security group associated with the DB instance.

columns.name: domain_memberships
columns.comment: A list of Active Directory Domain membership records associated with the DB instance.

columns.name: enabled_cloudwatch_logs_exports
columns.comment: A list of log types that this DB instance is configured to export to CloudWatch Logs.

columns.name: option_group_memberships
columns.comment: A list of option group memberships for this DB instance

columns.name: pending_maintenance_actions
columns.comment: A list that provides details about the pending maintenance actions for the resource.

columns.name: processor_features
columns.comment: The number of CPU cores and the number of threads per core for the DB instance class of the DB instance.

columns.name: read_replica_db_cluster_identifiers
columns.comment: A list of identifiers of Aurora DB clusters to which the RDS DB instance is replicated as a read replica.

columns.name: read_replica_db_instance_identifiers
columns.comment: A list of identifiers of the read replicas associated with this DB instance.

columns.name: status_infos
columns.comment: The status of a read replica.

columns.name: subnets
columns.comment: A list of subnet elements.

columns.name: vpc_security_groups
columns.comment: A list of VPC security group elements that the DB instance belongs to.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags attached to the DB Instance.

tables.name: aws.aws_cost_by_record_type_daily
tables.comment: AWS Cost Explorer - Cost by Record Type (Daily)

columns.name: linked_account_id
columns.comment: The linked AWS Account ID.

columns.name: record_type
columns.comment: The different types of charges such as RI fees, usage, costs, tax refunds, and credits.

columns.name: period_start
columns.comment: Start timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: period_end
columns.comment: End timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: estimated
columns.comment: Whether the result is estimated.

columns.name: blended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the average cost of usage across the consolidated billing family. If you use the consolidated billing feature in AWS Organizations, you can view costs using blended rates.

columns.name: blended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for blended costs.

columns.name: unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: Unblended costs represent your usage costs on the day they are charged to you. In finance terms, they represent your costs on a cash basis of accounting.

columns.name: unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for unblended costs.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the unblended cost after discounts.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net unblended costs.

columns.name: amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the effective cost of the upfront and monthly reservation fees spread across the billing period. By default, Cost Explorer shows the fees for Reserved Instances as a spike on the day that you're charged, but if you choose to show costs as amortized costs, the costs are amortized over the billing period. This means that the costs are broken out into the effective daily rate. AWS estimates your amortized costs by combining your unblended costs with the amortized portion of your upfront and recurring reservation fees.

columns.name: amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for amortized costs.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric amortizes the upfront and monthly reservation fees while including discounts such as RI volume discounts.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net amortized costs.

columns.name: usage_quantity_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred. NOTE: If you return the UsageQuantity metric, the service aggregates all usage numbers without taking into account the units. For example, if you aggregate usageQuantity across all of Amazon EC2, the results aren't meaningful because Amazon EC2 compute hours and data transfer are measured in different units (for example, hours vs. GB).

columns.name: usage_quantity_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for usage quantity.

columns.name: normalized_usage_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred, in normalized units, for size-flexible RIs. The NormalizedUsageAmount is equal to UsageAmount multiplied by NormalizationFactor.

columns.name: normalized_usage_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for normalized usage.

columns.comment: The broker's name.

columns.comment: The unique ID that Amazon MQ generates for the broker.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the broker.

columns.name: broker_state
columns.comment: The broker's status.

columns.name: deployment_mode
columns.comment: The broker's deployment mode.

columns.name: created
columns.comment: The time when the broker was created.

columns.name: host_instance_type
columns.comment: The broker's instance type.

columns.name: authentication_strategy
columns.comment: The authentication strategy used to secure the broker. The default is SIMPLE.

columns.name: data_replication_mode
columns.comment: Describes whether this broker is a part of a data replication pair.

columns.name: engine_type
columns.comment: The type of broker engine. Currently, Amazon MQ supports ACTIVEMQ and RABBITMQ.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: The broker engine's version.

columns.name: pending_authentication_strategy
columns.comment: The authentication strategy that will be applied when the broker is rebooted. The default is SIMPLE.

columns.name: pending_data_replication_mode
columns.comment: Describes whether this broker will be a part of a data replication pair after reboot.

columns.name: pending_engine_version
columns.comment: The broker engine version to upgrade to.

columns.name: pending_host_instance_type
columns.comment: The broker's host instance type to upgrade to.

columns.name: publicly_accessible
columns.comment: Enables connections from applications outside of the VPC that hosts the broker's subnets.

columns.name: storage_type
columns.comment: The broker's storage type.

columns.name: auto_minor_version_upgrade
columns.comment: Enables automatic upgrades to new minor versions for brokers, as new versions are released and supported by Amazon MQ.

columns.name: actions_required
columns.comment: Actions required for a broker.

columns.name: broker_instances
columns.comment: A list of information about allocated brokers.

columns.name: configurations
columns.comment: The list of all revisions for the specified configuration.

columns.name: data_replication_metadata
columns.comment: The replication details of the data replication-enabled broker. Only returned if dataReplicationMode is set to CRDR.

columns.name: encryption_options
columns.comment: Encryption options for the broker.

columns.name: ldap_server_metadata
columns.comment: The metadata of the LDAP server used to authenticate and authorize connections to the broker.

columns.name: logs
columns.comment: The list of information about logs currently enabled and pending to be deployed for the specified broker.

columns.name: pending_ldap_server_metadata
columns.comment: The metadata of the LDAP server that will be used to authenticate and authorize connections to the broker after it is rebooted.

columns.name: maintenance_window_start_time
columns.comment: The parameters that determine the WeeklyStartTime.

columns.name: pending_data_replication_metadata
columns.comment: The pending replication details of the data replication-enabled broker. Only returned if pendingDataReplicationMode is set to CRDR.

columns.name: pending_security_groups

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the record.

columns.name: zone_id
columns.comment: The ID of the hosted zone to contain this record.

columns.name: type
columns.comment: The record type. Valid values are A, AAAA, CAA, CNAME, MX, NAPTR, NS, PTR, SOA, SPF, SRV and TXT.

columns.name: alias_target
columns.comment: Alias resource record sets only: Information about the AWS resource, such as a CloudFront distribution or an Amazon S3 bucket, that you want to route traffic to.

columns.name: failover
columns.comment: Failover resource record sets only: To configure failover, you add the Failover element to two resource record sets. For one resource record set, you specify PRIMARY as the value for Failover; for the other resource record set, you specify SECONDARY. In addition, you include the HealthCheckId element and specify the health check that you want Amazon Route 53 to perform for each resource record set.

columns.name: geo_location
columns.comment: Geolocation resource record sets only: A complex type that lets you control how Amazon Route 53 responds to DNS queries based on the geographic origin of the query. For example, if you want all queries from Africa to be routed to a web server with an IP address of 192.0.2.111, create a resource record set with a Type of A and a ContinentCode of AF.

columns.name: health_check_id
columns.comment: The health check the record should be associated with.

columns.name: multi_value_answer
columns.comment: Multivalue answer resource record sets only: To route traffic approximately randomly to multiple resources, such as web servers, create one multivalue answer record for each resource and specify true for MultiValueAnswer.

columns.name: latency_region
columns.comment: An AWS region from which to measure latency

columns.name: records
columns.comment: If the health check or hosted zone was created by another service, an optional description that can be provided by the other service.

columns.name: set_identifier
columns.comment: Unique identifier to differentiate records with routing policies from one another.

columns.name: ttl
columns.comment: The resource record cache time to live (TTL), in seconds.

columns.name: traffic_policy_instance_id
columns.comment: The ID of the traffic policy instance that Route 53 created this resource record set for.

columns.name: weight
columns.comment: Weighted resource record sets only: Among resource record sets that have the same combination of DNS name and type, a value that determines the proportion of DNS queries that Amazon Route 53 responds to using the current resource record set. Route 53 calculates the sum of the weights for the resource record sets that have the same combination of DNS name and type. Route 53 then responds to queries based on the ratio of a resource's weight to the total.
