columns.comment: The route key for the route.

columns.name: api_id
columns.comment: Represents the identifier of an API.

columns.name: route_id
columns.comment: The route ID.

columns.name: api_gateway_managed
columns.comment: Specifies whether a route is managed by API Gateway.

columns.name: api_key_required
columns.comment: Specifies whether an API key is required for this route. Supported only for WebSocket APIs.

columns.name: authorization_type
columns.comment: The authorization type for the route. For WebSocket APIs, valid values are NONE for open access, AWS_IAM for using AWS IAM permissions, and CUSTOM for using a Lambda authorizer For HTTP APIs, valid values are NONE for open access, JWT for using JSON Web Tokens, AWS_IAM for using AWS IAM permissions, and CUSTOM for using a Lambda authorizer.

columns.name: authorizer_id
columns.comment: The identifier of the Authorizer resource to be associated with this route. The authorizer identifier is generated by API Gateway when you created the authorizer.

columns.name: model_selection_expression
columns.comment: The model selection expression for the route. Supported only for WebSocket APIs.

columns.name: operation_name
columns.comment: The operation name for the route.

columns.name: route_response_selection_expression
columns.comment: The route response selection expression for the route. Supported only for WebSocket APIs.

columns.name: target
columns.comment: The target for the route.

columns.name: authorization_scopes
columns.comment: A list of authorization scopes configured on a route. The scopes are used with a JWT authorizer to authorize the method invocation. The authorization works by matching the route scopes against the scopes parsed from the access token in the incoming request. The method invocation is authorized if any route scope matches a claimed scope in the access token. Otherwise, the invocation is not authorized. When the route scope is configured, the client must provide an access token instead of an identity token for authorization purposes.

columns.name: request_models
columns.comment: The request models for the route. Supported only for WebSocket APIs.

columns.name: request_parameters
columns.comment: The request parameters for the route. Supported only for WebSocket APIs.

tables.name: aws.aws_cost_by_service_daily
tables.comment: AWS Cost Explorer - Cost by Service (Daily)

columns.name: service
columns.comment: The name of the AWS service.

columns.name: cost_source
columns.comment: The source of the cost.

columns.name: period_start
columns.comment: Start timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: period_end
columns.comment: End timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: estimated
columns.comment: Whether the result is estimated.

columns.name: blended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the average cost of usage across the consolidated billing family. If you use the consolidated billing feature in AWS Organizations, you can view costs using blended rates.

columns.name: blended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for blended costs.

columns.name: unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: Unblended costs represent your usage costs on the day they are charged to you. In finance terms, they represent your costs on a cash basis of accounting.

columns.name: unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for unblended costs.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the unblended cost after discounts.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net unblended costs.

columns.name: amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the effective cost of the upfront and monthly reservation fees spread across the billing period. By default, Cost Explorer shows the fees for Reserved Instances as a spike on the day that you're charged, but if you choose to show costs as amortized costs, the costs are amortized over the billing period. This means that the costs are broken out into the effective daily rate. AWS estimates your amortized costs by combining your unblended costs with the amortized portion of your upfront and recurring reservation fees.

columns.name: amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for amortized costs.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric amortizes the upfront and monthly reservation fees while including discounts such as RI volume discounts.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net amortized costs.

columns.name: usage_quantity_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred. NOTE: If you return the UsageQuantity metric, the service aggregates all usage numbers without taking into account the units. For example, if you aggregate usageQuantity across all of Amazon EC2, the results aren't meaningful because Amazon EC2 compute hours and data transfer are measured in different units (for example, hours vs. GB).

columns.name: usage_quantity_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for usage quantity.

columns.name: normalized_usage_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred, in normalized units, for size-flexible RIs. The NormalizedUsageAmount is equal to UsageAmount multiplied by NormalizationFactor.

columns.name: normalized_usage_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for normalized usage.

columns.comment: The ARN of the AWS S3 Bucket.

columns.comment: The date and tiem when bucket was created.

columns.comment: The policy status for an Amazon S3 bucket, indicating whether the bucket is public.

columns.comment: The versioning state of a bucket.

columns.name: versioning_mfa_delete
columns.comment: The MFA Delete status of the versioning state.

columns.name: block_public_acls
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should block public access control lists (ACLs) for this bucket and objects in this bucket.

columns.name: block_public_policy
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should block public bucket policies for this bucket. If TRUE it causes Amazon S3 to reject calls to PUT Bucket policy if the specified bucket policy allows public access.

columns.name: ignore_public_acls
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should ignore public ACLs for this bucket and objects in this bucket. Setting this element to TRUE causes Amazon S3 to ignore all public ACLs on this bucket and objects in this bucket.

columns.name: restrict_public_buckets
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should restrict public bucket policies for this bucket. Setting this element to TRUE restricts access to this bucket to only AWS service principals and authorized users within this account if the bucket has a public policy.

columns.name: event_notification_configuration
columns.comment: A container for specifying the notification configuration of the bucket. If this element is empty, notifications are turned off for the bucket.

columns.name: server_side_encryption_configuration
columns.comment: The default encryption configuration for an Amazon S3 bucket.

columns.name: acl
columns.comment: The access control list (ACL) of a bucket.

columns.name: lifecycle_rules
columns.comment: The lifecycle configuration information of the bucket.

columns.name: logging
columns.comment: The logging status of a bucket and the permissions users have to view and modify that status.

columns.name: object_lock_configuration
columns.comment: The specified bucket's object lock configuration.

columns.name: object_ownership_controls
columns.comment: The Ownership Controls for an Amazon S3 bucket.

columns.name: policy
columns.comment: The resource IAM access document for the bucket.

columns.name: policy_std
columns.comment: Contains the policy in a canonical form for easier searching.

columns.name: replication
columns.comment: The replication configuration of a bucket.

columns.name: website_configuration
columns.comment: The website configuration information of the bucket.

columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to bucket.

columns.comment: The date and time that the query completed.

columns.comment: An integer value that specifies the category of a query failure error.

columns.comment: The number of milliseconds that the query was in your query queue waiting for resources.

columns.name: service_processing_time_in_millis

columns.comment: Indicates whether Amazon S3 server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed keys (SSE_S3), server-side encryption with KMS-managed keys (SSE_KMS), or client-side encryption with KMS-managed keys (CSE_KMS) is used.

columns.name: output_location
columns.comment: The location in Amazon S3 where your query results are stored.

columns.comment: True if previous query results can be reused when the query is run.

columns.name: result_reuse_by_age_mag_age_in_minutes
columns.comment: Specifies, in minutes, the maximum age of a previous query result that Athena should consider for reuse. The default is 60.

columns.name: db_cluster_snapshot_identifier
columns.comment: Specifies the identifier for a DB cluster snapshot. Must match the identifier of an existing snapshot.

columns.name: db_cluster_snapshot_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: snapshot_type
columns.comment: Provides the type of the DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: Specifies the status of this DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: db_cluster_identifier
columns.comment: Specifies the DB cluster identifier of the DB cluster that this DB cluster snapshot was created from.

columns.name: cluster_create_time
columns.comment: Specifies the time when the DB cluster was created, in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC).

columns.name: allocated_storage
columns.comment: Specifies the allocated storage size in gibibytes (GiB).

columns.name: snapshot_create_time
columns.comment: Provides the time when the snapshot was taken, in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC).

columns.name: percent_progress
columns.comment: Specifies the percentage of the estimated data that has been transferred.

columns.name: source_db_cluster_snapshot_arn
columns.comment: If the DB cluster snapshot was copied from a source DB cluster snapshot, the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the source DB cluster snapshot, otherwise, a null value.

columns.name: engine
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the database engine.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: Provides the version of the database engine for this DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
columns.comment: True if mapping of Amazon Identity and Access Management (IAM) accounts to database accounts is enabled, and otherwise false.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: If StorageEncrypted is true, the Amazon KMS key identifier for the encrypted DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: license_model
columns.comment: Provides the license model information for this DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: master_username
columns.comment: Not supported by Neptune.

columns.name: port
columns.comment: Specifies the port that the DB cluster was listening on at the time of the snapshot.

columns.name: storage_encrypted
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB cluster snapshot is encrypted.

columns.name: vpc_id
columns.comment: Provides the VPC ID associated with the DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: availability_zones
columns.comment: Provides the list of EC2 Availability Zones that instances in the DB cluster snapshot can be restored in.

columns.name: db_cluster_snapshot_attributes
columns.comment: A list of DB cluster snapshot attribute names and values for a manual DB cluster snapshot.

columns.comment: The friendly name to identify the DB Instance.

columns.comment: The name of the metric.

columns.name: namespace
columns.comment: The metric namespace.

columns.name: average
columns.comment: The average of the metric values that correspond to the data point.

columns.name: maximum
columns.comment: The maximum metric value for the data point.

columns.name: minimum
columns.comment: The minimum metric value for the data point.

columns.name: sample_count
columns.comment: The number of metric values that contributed to the aggregate value of this data point.

columns.name: sum
columns.comment: The sum of the metric values for the data point.

columns.name: unit
columns.comment: The standard unit for the data point.

columns.name: timestamp

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name for the Resolver rule, which you specified when you created the Resolver rule.

columns.name: id
columns.comment: The ID that Resolver assigned to the Resolver rule when you created it.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The ARN (Amazon Resource Name) for the Resolver rule specified by Id.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: A code that specifies the current status of the Resolver rule.

columns.name: creator_request_id
columns.comment: A unique string that you specified when you created the Resolver rule. CreatorRequestId identifies the request and allows failed requests to be retried without the risk of executing the operation twice.

columns.name: domain_name
columns.comment: DNS queries for this domain name are forwarded to the IP addresses that are specified in TargetIps.

columns.name: owner_id
columns.comment: When a rule is shared with another AWS account, the account ID of the account that the rule is shared with.

columns.name: resolver_endpoint_id
columns.comment: The ID of the endpoint that the rule is associated with.

columns.name: rule_type
columns.comment: When you want to forward DNS queries for specified domain name to resolvers on your network, specify FORWARD.When you have a forwarding rule to forward DNS queries for a domain to your network and you want Resolver to process queries for a subdomain of that domain, specify SYSTEM.

columns.name: share_status
columns.comment: Indicates whether the rules is shared and, if so, whether the current account is sharing the rule with another account, or another account is sharing the rule with the current account.

columns.name: status_message
columns.comment: A detailed description of the status of a Resolver rule.

columns.name: creation_time
columns.comment: The date and time that the Resolver rule was created, in Unix time format and Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

columns.name: modification_time
columns.comment: The date and time that the Resolver rule was last updated, in Unix time format and Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

columns.name: resolver_rule_associations
columns.comment: The associations that were created between Resolver rules and VPCs using the current AWS account, and that match the specified filters, if any.

columns.name: target_ips
columns.comment: An array that contains the IP addresses and ports that an outbound endpoint forwards DNS queries to. Typically, these are the IP addresses of DNS resolvers on your network. Specify IPv4 addresses. IPv6 is not supported.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to the Resolver Rule.

columns.comment: The basic authorization credentials for branches for the Amplify app. You must base64-encode the authorization credentials and provide them in the format user:password.

columns.comment: The default domain for the Amplify app.

columns.comment: Enables automated branch creation for the Amplify app.

columns.comment: Enables the auto-building of branches for the Amplify app.

columns.comment: Automatically disconnect a branch in the Amplify Console when you delete a branch from your Git repository.

columns.name: repository_clone_method
columns.comment: The Amplify service uses this parameter to specify the authentication protocol to use to access the Git repository for an Amplify app. Amplify specifies TOKEN for a GitHub repository, SIGV4 for an AWS CodeCommit repository, and SSH for GitLab and Bitbucket repositories.

columns.comment: Describes the automated branch creation configuration for the Amplify app.

columns.name: build_spec

columns.name: custom_rules
columns.comment: Describes the custom redirect and rewrite rules for the Amplify app.

columns.name: environment_variables
columns.comment: The environment variables for the Amplify app.

columns.name: production_branch
columns.comment: Describes the information about a production branch of the Amplify app.

columns.name: db_cluster_identifier
columns.comment: The friendly name to identify the DB Cluster.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the DB Cluster.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: Specifies the status of this DB Cluster.

columns.name: resource_id
columns.comment: The AWS Region-unique, immutable identifier for the DB cluster.

columns.name: create_time
columns.comment: Specifies the time when the DB cluster was created.

columns.name: activity_stream_kinesis_stream_name
columns.comment: The name of the Amazon Kinesis data stream used for the database activity stream.

columns.name: activity_stream_kms_key_id
columns.comment: The AWS KMS key identifier used for encrypting messages in the database activity stream.

columns.name: activity_stream_mode
columns.comment: The mode of the database activity stream.

columns.name: activity_stream_status
columns.comment: The status of the database activity stream.

columns.name: allocated_storage
columns.comment: Specifies the allocated storage size in gibibytes (GiB).

columns.name: auto_minor_version_upgrade
columns.comment: A value that indicates that minor version patches are applied automatically. This setting is only for non-Aurora Multi-AZ DB clusters.

columns.name: backtrack_consumed_change_records
columns.comment: The number of change records stored for Backtrack.

columns.name: backtrack_window
columns.comment: The target backtrack window, in seconds.

columns.name: backup_retention_period
columns.comment: Specifies the number of days for which automatic DB snapshots are retained.

columns.name: capacity
columns.comment: The current capacity of an Aurora Serverless DB cluster.

columns.name: character_set_name
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the character set that this cluster is associated with.

columns.name: clone_group_id
columns.comment: Identifies the clone group to which the DB cluster is associated.

columns.name: copy_tags_to_snapshot
columns.comment: Specifies whether tags are copied from the DB cluster to snapshots of the DB cluster, or not.

columns.name: cross_account_clone
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB cluster is a clone of a DB cluster owned by a different AWS account, or not.

columns.name: database_name
columns.comment: Contains the name of the initial database of this DB cluster that was provided at create time.

columns.name: db_cluster_parameter_group
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the DB cluster parameter group for the DB cluster.

columns.name: db_subnet_group
columns.comment: Specifies information on the subnet group associated with the DB cluster.

columns.name: deletion_protection
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB cluster has deletion protection enabled, or not.

columns.name: earliest_backtrack_time
columns.comment: The earliest time to which a DB cluster can be backtracked.

columns.name: earliest_restorable_time
columns.comment: The earliest time to which a database can be restored with point-in-time restore.

columns.name: endpoint
columns.comment: Specifies the connection endpoint for the primary instance of the DB cluster.

columns.name: engine
columns.comment: The name of the database engine to be used for this DB cluster.

columns.name: engine_mode
columns.comment: The DB engine mode of the DB cluster.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: Indicates the database engine version.

columns.name: global_write_forwarding_requested
columns.comment: Specifies whether you have requested to enable write forwarding for a secondary cluster in an Aurora global database, or not.

columns.name: global_write_forwarding_status
columns.comment: Specifies whether a secondary cluster in an Aurora global database has write forwarding enabled, or not.

columns.name: hosted_zone_id
columns.comment: Specifies the ID that Amazon Route 53 assigns when you create a hosted zone.

columns.name: http_endpoint_enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether the HTTP endpoint for an Aurora Serverless DB cluster is enabled, or not.

columns.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether the the mapping of AWS IAM accounts to database accounts is enabled, or not.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: The AWS KMS key identifier for the encrypted DB cluster.

columns.name: latest_restorable_time
columns.comment: Specifies the latest time to which a database can be restored with point-in-time restore.

columns.name: master_user_name
columns.comment: Contains the master username for the DB cluster.

columns.name: multi_az
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB cluster has instances in multiple Availability Zones, or not.

columns.name: percent_progress
columns.comment: Specifies the progress of the operation as a percentage.

columns.name: port
columns.comment: Specifies the port that the database engine is listening on.

columns.name: preferred_backup_window
columns.comment: Specifies the daily time range during which automated backups are created.

columns.name: preferred_maintenance_window
columns.comment: Specifies the weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur

columns.name: reader_endpoint
columns.comment: The reader endpoint for the DB cluster.

columns.name: storage_encrypted
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB cluster is encrypted, or not.

columns.name: associated_roles
columns.comment: A list of AWS IAM roles that are associated with the DB cluster.

columns.name: availability_zones
columns.comment: A list of Availability Zones (AZs) where instances in the DB cluster can be created.

columns.name: custom_endpoints
columns.comment: A list of all custom endpoints associated with the cluster.

columns.name: members
columns.comment: A list of instances that make up the DB cluster.

columns.name: option_group_memberships
columns.comment: A list of option group memberships for this DB cluster.

columns.name: domain_memberships
columns.comment: A list of Active Directory Domain membership records associated with the DB cluster.

columns.name: enabled_cloudwatch_logs_exports
columns.comment: A list of log types that this DB cluster is configured to export to CloudWatch Logs.

columns.name: pending_maintenance_actions
columns.comment: A list that provides details about the pending maintenance actions for the resource.

columns.name: read_replica_identifiers
columns.comment: A list of identifiers of the read replicas associated with this DB cluster.

columns.name: vpc_security_groups
columns.comment: A list of VPC security groups that the DB cluster belongs to.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags attached to the DB Cluster.

tables.name: aws.aws_cost_by_account_daily
tables.comment: AWS Cost Explorer - Cost by Linked Account (Daily)

columns.name: linked_account_id
columns.comment: The AWS Account ID.

columns.name: period_start
columns.comment: Start timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: period_end
columns.comment: End timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: estimated
columns.comment: Whether the result is estimated.

columns.name: blended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the average cost of usage across the consolidated billing family. If you use the consolidated billing feature in AWS Organizations, you can view costs using blended rates.

columns.name: blended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for blended costs.

columns.name: unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: Unblended costs represent your usage costs on the day they are charged to you. In finance terms, they represent your costs on a cash basis of accounting.

columns.name: unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for unblended costs.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the unblended cost after discounts.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net unblended costs.

columns.name: amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the effective cost of the upfront and monthly reservation fees spread across the billing period. By default, Cost Explorer shows the fees for Reserved Instances as a spike on the day that you're charged, but if you choose to show costs as amortized costs, the costs are amortized over the billing period. This means that the costs are broken out into the effective daily rate. AWS estimates your amortized costs by combining your unblended costs with the amortized portion of your upfront and recurring reservation fees.

columns.name: amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for amortized costs.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric amortizes the upfront and monthly reservation fees while including discounts such as RI volume discounts.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net amortized costs.

columns.name: usage_quantity_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred. NOTE: If you return the UsageQuantity metric, the service aggregates all usage numbers without taking into account the units. For example, if you aggregate usageQuantity across all of Amazon EC2, the results aren't meaningful because Amazon EC2 compute hours and data transfer are measured in different units (for example, hours vs. GB).

columns.name: usage_quantity_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for usage quantity.

columns.name: normalized_usage_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred, in normalized units, for size-flexible RIs. The NormalizedUsageAmount is equal to UsageAmount multiplied by NormalizationFactor.

columns.name: normalized_usage_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for normalized usage.

tables.name: aws.aws_ssm_managed_instance_patch_state
tables.comment: AWS SSM Managed Instance Patch State

columns.name: instance_id
columns.comment: The ID of the managed node the high-level patch compliance information was collected for.

columns.name: baseline_id
columns.comment: The ID of the patch baseline used to patch the managed node.

columns.name: operation
columns.comment: The type of patching operation that was performed.

columns.name: operation_end_time
columns.comment: The time the most recent patching operation completed on the managed node.

columns.name: operation_start_time
columns.comment: The time the most recent patching operation was started on the managed node.

columns.name: patch_group
columns.comment: The name of the patch group the managed node belongs to.

columns.name: critical_non_compliant_count
columns.comment: The number of patches per node that are specified as Critical for compliance reporting in the patch baseline aren't installed. These patches might be missing, have failed installation, were rejected, or were installed but awaiting a required managed node reboot. The status of these managed nodes is NON_COMPLIANT.

columns.name: failed_count
columns.comment: The number of patches from the patch baseline that were attempted to be installed during the last patching operation, but failed to install.

columns.name: installed_count
columns.comment: The number of patches from the patch baseline that are installed on the managed node.

columns.name: installed_other_count
columns.comment: The number of patches not specified in the patch baseline that are installed on the managed node.

columns.name: installed_pending_reboot_count
columns.comment: The number of patches installed by Patch Manager since the last time the managed node was rebooted.

columns.name: installed_rejected_count
columns.comment: The number of patches installed on a managed node that are specified in a RejectedPatches list. Patches with a status of InstalledRejected were typically installed before they were added to a RejectedPatches list.

columns.name: last_no_reboot_install_operation_time
columns.comment: The time of the last attempt to patch the managed node with NoReboot specified as the reboot option.

columns.name: missing_count
columns.comment: The number of patches from the patch baseline that are applicable for the managed node but aren't currently installed.

columns.name: not_applicable_count
columns.comment: The number of patches from the patch baseline that aren't applicable for the managed node and therefore aren't installed on the node. This number may be truncated if the list of patch names is very large. The number of patches beyond this limit are reported in UnreportedNotApplicableCount.

columns.name: other_non_compliant_count
columns.comment: The number of patches per node that are specified as other than Critical or Security but aren't compliant with the patch baseline. The status of these managed nodes is NON_COMPLIANT.

columns.name: owner_information
columns.comment: Placeholder information. This field will always be empty in the current release of the service.

columns.name: reboot_option
columns.comment: Indicates the reboot option specified in the patch baseline. Reboot options apply to Install operations only. Reboots aren't attempted for Patch Manager Scan operations.

columns.name: security_non_compliant_count
columns.comment: The number of patches per node that are specified as Security in a patch advisory aren't installed. These patches might be missing, have failed installation, were rejected, or were installed but awaiting a required managed node reboot. The status of these managed nodes is NON_COMPLIANT.

columns.name: snapshot_id
columns.comment: The ID of the patch baseline snapshot used during the patching operation when this compliance data was collected.

columns.name: unreported_not_applicable_count
columns.comment: The number of patches beyond the supported limit of NotApplicableCount that aren't reported by name to Inventory. Inventory is a capability of Amazon Web Services Systems Manager.

columns.comment: Indicates whether this access point policy is public, or not.

columns.name: block_public_acls
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should block public access control lists (ACLs) for buckets in this account.

columns.name: block_public_policy
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should block public bucket policies for buckets in this account.

columns.name: ignore_public_acls
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should ignore public ACLs for buckets in this account.

columns.name: restrict_public_buckets
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should restrict public bucket policies for buckets in this account.

columns.comment: The date and time when the specified access point was created.

columns.name: network_origin
columns.comment: Indicates whether this access point allows access from the public internet. If VpcConfiguration is specified for this access point, then NetworkOrigin is VPC, and the access point doesn't allow access from the public internet.

columns.name: vpc_id
columns.comment: Specifies the VPC ID from which the access point will only allow connections.

columns.comment: Specifies the current state of this cluster.

columns.comment: Specifies the time when the cluster was created.

columns.comment: Specifies the number of days for which automatic snapshots are retained.

columns.name: clone_group_id
columns.comment: Identifies the clone group to which the DB cluster is associated.

columns.name: db_cluster_parameter_group
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the cluster parameter group for the cluster.

columns.name: db_cluster_resource_id
columns.comment: The Region-unique, immutable identifier for the cluster.

columns.name: db_subnet_group
columns.comment: Specifies information on the subnet group associated with the cluster.

columns.name: deletion_protection
columns.comment: Specifies whether the cluster has deletion protection enabled, or not.

columns.comment: The earliest time to which a database can be restored with point-in-time restore.

columns.name: endpoint
columns.comment: Specifies the connection endpoint for the primary instance of the DB cluster.

columns.name: engine
columns.comment: The name of the database engine to be used for this DB cluster.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: Indicates the database engine version.

columns.name: hosted_zone_id
columns.comment: Specifies the ID that Amazon Route 53 assigns when you create a hosted zone.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: The AWS KMS key identifier for the encrypted cluster.

columns.name: latest_restorable_time
columns.comment: Specifies the latest time to which a database can be restored with point-in-time restore.

columns.name: master_user_name
columns.comment: Contains the master username for the cluster.

columns.name: multi_az
columns.comment: Specifies whether the cluster has instances in multiple Availability Zones, or not.

columns.name: percent_progress
columns.comment: Specifies the progress of the operation as a percentage.

columns.name: port
columns.comment: Specifies the port that the database engine is listening on.

columns.name: preferred_backup_window
columns.comment: Specifies the daily time range during which automated backups are created.

columns.name: preferred_maintenance_window
columns.comment: Specifies the weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur

columns.name: reader_endpoint
columns.comment: The reader endpoint for the DB cluster.

columns.name: replication_source_identifier
columns.comment: Contains the identifier of the source cluster if this cluster is a secondary cluster.

columns.name: storage_encrypted
columns.comment: Specifies whether the cluster is encrypted, or not.

columns.comment: A list of AWS IAM roles that are associated with the cluster.

columns.name: availability_zones
columns.comment: A list of Availability Zones (AZs) where instances in the cluster can be created.

columns.comment: A list of identifiers of the read replicas associated with this cluster.

columns.comment: A list of VPC security groups that the DB cluster belongs to.

columns.comment: A list of tags attached to the Cluster.

columns.comment: It indicate the evaluation status for the AWS Config rule.

columns.comment: The compliance information of the config rule.

columns.comment: The modes the Config rule can be evaluated in. The valid values are distinct objects. By default, the value is Detective evaluation mode only.

columns.name: input_parameters
columns.comment: A string, in JSON format, that is passed to the AWS Config rule Lambda function.

columns.name: scope
columns.comment: Defines which resources can trigger an evaluation for the rule. The scope can include one or more resource types, a combination of one resource type and one resource ID, or a combination of a tag key and value. Specify a scope to constrain the resources that can trigger an evaluation for the rule. If you do not specify a scope, evaluations are triggered when any resource in the recording group changes.

columns.name: source
columns.comment: Provides the rule owner (AWS or customer), the rule identifier, and the notifications that cause the function to evaluate your AWS resources.

columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to the rule.

columns.name: role_last_used_date
columns.comment: Contains information about the last time that an IAM role was used. Activity is only reported for the trailing 400 days. This period can be shorter if your Region began supporting these features within the last year. The role might have been used more than 400 days ago.

columns.name: assume_role_policy
columns.comment: The policy that grants an entity permission to assume the role.

columns.name: assume_role_policy_std

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the AMI that was provided during image creation.

columns.name: image_id
columns.comment: The ID of the AMI.

columns.name: state
columns.comment: The current state of the AMI. If the state is available, the image is successfully registered and can be used to launch an instance.

columns.name: image_type
columns.comment: The type of image.

columns.name: image_location
columns.comment: The location of the AMI.

columns.name: creation_date
columns.comment: The date and time when the image was created.

columns.name: architecture
columns.comment: The architecture of the image.

columns.name: description
columns.comment: The description of the AMI that was provided during image creation.

columns.name: ena_support
columns.comment: Specifies whether enhanced networking with ENA is enabled.

columns.name: hypervisor
columns.comment: The hypervisor type of the image.

columns.name: image_owner_alias
columns.comment: The AWS account alias (for example, amazon, self) or the AWS account ID of the AMI owner.

columns.name: imds_support
columns.comment: If v2.0, it indicates that IMDSv2 is specified in the AMI.

columns.name: kernel_id
columns.comment: The kernel associated with the image, if any. Only applicable for machine images.

columns.name: owner_id
columns.comment: The AWS account ID of the image owner.

columns.name: platform
columns.comment: This value is set to windows for Windows AMIs; otherwise, it is blank.

columns.name: platform_details
columns.comment: The platform details associated with the billing code of the AMI. For more information, see Obtaining Billing Information (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ami-billing-info.html) in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

columns.name: public
columns.comment: Indicates whether the image has public launch permissions. The value is true if this image has public launch permissions or false if it has only implicit and explicit launch permissions.

columns.name: ramdisk_id
columns.comment: The RAM disk associated with the image, if any. Only applicable for machine images.

columns.name: root_device_name
columns.comment: The device name of the root device volume (for example, /dev/sda1).

columns.name: root_device_type
columns.comment: The type of root device used by the AMI. The AMI can use an EBS volume or an instance store volume.

columns.name: sriov_net_support
columns.comment: Specifies whether enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface is enabled.

columns.name: usage_operation
columns.comment: The operation of the Amazon EC2 instance and the billing code that is associated with the AMI. For the list of UsageOperation codes, see Platform Details and [Usage Operation Billing Codes](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ami-billing-info.html#billing-info) in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

columns.name: virtualization_type
columns.comment: The type of virtualization of the AMI.

columns.name: block_device_mappings
columns.comment: Any block device mapping entries.

columns.name: product_codes
columns.comment: Any product codes associated with the AMI.

columns.name: launch_permissions
columns.comment: The users and groups that have the permissions for creating instances from the AMI.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags attached to the AMI.

columns.comment: Is backup managed by AWS

columns.name: snapshot_identifier
columns.comment: The unique identifier of the cluster.

columns.name: cluster_identifier
columns.comment: The identifier of the cluster for which the snapshot was taken.

columns.name: snapshot_type
columns.comment: The snapshot type.

columns.name: actual_incremental_backup_size_in_mega_bytes
columns.comment: The size of the incremental backup.

columns.name: availability_zone
columns.comment: The Availability Zone in which the cluster was created.

columns.name: backup_progress_in_mega-bytes
columns.comment: The number of megabytes that have been transferred to the snapshot backup.

columns.name: cluster_create_time
columns.comment: The time (UTC) when the cluster was originally created.

columns.name: cluster_version
columns.comment: The version ID of the Amazon Redshift engine that is running on the cluster.

columns.name: current_backup_rate_in_mega_bytes_per_second
columns.comment: The number of megabytes per second being transferred to the snapshot backup.

columns.name: db_name
columns.comment: The name of the database that was created when the cluster was created.

columns.name: elapsed_time_in_seconds
columns.comment: The amount of time an in-progress snapshot backup has been running, or the amount of time it took a completed backup to finish.

columns.name: encrypted
columns.comment: If true, the data in the snapshot is encrypted at rest.

columns.name: encrypted_with_hsm
columns.comment: A boolean that indicates whether the snapshot data is encrypted using the HSM keys of the source cluster.

columns.name: engine_full_version
columns.comment: The cluster version of the cluster used to create the snapshot.

columns.name: enhanced_vpc_routing
columns.comment: An option that specifies whether to create the cluster with enhanced VPC routing enabled.

columns.name: estimated_seconds_to_completion
columns.comment: The estimate of the time remaining before the snapshot backup will complete.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: The AWS KMS key ID of the encryption key that was used to encrypt data in the cluster from which the snapshot was taken.

columns.name: maintenance_track_name
columns.comment: The name of the maintenance track for the snapshot.

columns.name: manual_snapshot_remaining_days
columns.comment: The number of days until a manual snapshot will pass its retention period.

columns.name: manual_snapshot_retention_period
columns.comment: The number of days that a manual snapshot is retained.

columns.name: master_username
columns.comment: The master user name for the cluster.

columns.name: node_type
columns.comment: The node type of the nodes in the cluster.

columns.name: number_of_nodes
columns.comment: The number of nodes in the cluster.

columns.name: owner_account
columns.comment: The AWS customer account used to create or copy the snapshot.

columns.name: port
columns.comment: The port that the cluster is listening on.

columns.name: snapshot_create_time
columns.comment: The time (in UTC format) when Amazon Redshift began the snapshot.

columns.name: snapshot_retention_start_time
columns.comment: A timestamp representing the start of the retention period for the snapshot.

columns.name: source_region
columns.comment: The source region from which the snapshot was copied.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: The snapshot status.

columns.name: total_backup_size_in_mega_bytes
columns.comment: The size of the complete set of backup data that would be used to restore the cluster.

columns.name: vpc_id
columns.comment: The VPC identifier of the cluster if the snapshot is from a cluster in a VPC.

columns.name: accounts_with_restore_access
columns.comment: A list of the AWS customer accounts authorized to restore the snapshot.

columns.name: restorable_node_types
columns.comment: The list of node types that this cluster snapshot is able to restore into.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: The list of tags for the cluster.

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the instance group.

columns.name: id
columns.comment: The identifier of the instance group.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) specifying the instance group.

columns.name: cluster_id
columns.comment: The unique identifier for the cluster.

columns.name: instance_group_type
columns.comment: The type of the instance group. Valid values are MASTER, CORE or TASK.

columns.name: instance_type
columns.comment: The EC2 instance type for all instances in the instance group.

columns.name: state
columns.comment: The current state of the instance group.

columns.name: bid_price
columns.comment: The maximum price you are willing to pay for Spot Instances. If specified, indicates that the instance group uses Spot Instances.

columns.name: configurations_version
columns.comment: The version number of the requested configuration specification for this instance group.

columns.name: ebs_optimized
columns.comment: Indicates whether the instance group is EBS-optimized, or not.  An Amazon EBS-optimized instance uses an optimized configuration stack and provides additional, dedicated capacity for Amazon EBS I/O.

columns.name: last_successfully_applied_configurations_version
columns.comment: The version number of a configuration specification that was successfully applied for an instance group last time.

columns.name: market
columns.comment: The marketplace to provision instances for this group. Valid values are ON_DEMAND or SPOT.

columns.name: requested_instance_count
columns.comment: The target number of instances for the instance group.

columns.name: running_instance_count
columns.comment: The number of instances currently running in this instance group.

columns.name: autoscaling_policy
columns.comment: An automatic scaling policy for a core instance group or task instance group in an Amazon EMR cluster.

columns.name: configurations
columns.comment: A list of configurations supplied for an EMR cluster instance group. Only availbale for Amazon EMR releases 4.x or later.

columns.name: ebs_block_devices
columns.comment: The EBS block devices that are mapped to this instance group.

columns.name: last_successfully_applied_configurations
columns.comment: A list of configurations that were successfully applied for an instance group last time.

columns.name: shrink_policy
columns.comment: Policy for customizing shrink operations.

columns.name: state_change_reason
columns.comment: The status change reason details for the instance group.

columns.name: status_timeline
columns.comment: The timeline of the instance group status over time.

columns.name: abuse_contact_email
columns.comment: Email address to contact to report incorrect contact information for a domain,to report that the domain is being used to send spam, to report that someone is cyber squatting on a domain name, or report some other type of abuse.

columns.name: abuse_contact_phone
columns.comment: Phone number for reporting abuse.

columns.name: admin_privacy
columns.comment: Specifies whether contact information is concealed from WHOIS queries.

columns.name: auto_renew
columns.comment: Indicates whether the domain is automatically renewed upon expiration.

columns.name: creation_date
columns.comment: The date when the domain was created as found in the response to a WHOIS query.

columns.name: expiration_date
columns.comment: The date when the registration for the domain is set to expire. The date and time is in Unix time format and Coordinated Universal time (UTC).

columns.name: registrant_privacy
columns.comment: Specifies whether contact information is concealed from WHOIS queries.

columns.name: registrar_name
columns.comment: Name of the registrar of the domain as identified in the registry. Domains with a .com, .net, or .org TLD are registered by Amazon Registrar.

columns.name: registrar_url
columns.comment: Web address of the registrar.

columns.name: registry_domain_id
columns.comment: Reserved for future use.

columns.name: reseller
columns.comment: Reseller of the domain. Domains registered or transferred using Route 53 domains will have Amazon as the reseller.

columns.name: tech_privacy
columns.comment: Specifies whether contact information is concealed from WHOIS queries.

columns.name: transfer_lock
columns.comment: Indicates whether a domain is locked from unauthorized transfer to another party.

columns.name: updated_date
columns.comment: The last updated date of the domain as found in the response to a WHOIS query.The date and time is in Unix time format and Coordinated Universal time (UTC).

columns.name: who_is_server
columns.comment: The fully qualified name of the WHOIS server that can answer the WHOIS query for the domain.

columns.name: nameservers
columns.comment: The name of the domain.

columns.name: registrant_contact
columns.comment: Provides details about the domain registrant.

columns.name: status_list
columns.comment: An array of domain name status codes, also known as Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) status codes.

columns.name: tech_contact
columns.comment: Provides details about the domain technical contact.

columns.name: admin_contact
columns.comment: Provides details about the domain administrative contact.

columns.comment: The current status of this DevEndpoint.

columns.name: availability_zone
columns.comment: The AWS Availability Zone where this DevEndpoint is located.

columns.name: created_timestamp
columns.comment: The point in time at which this DevEndpoint was created.

columns.name: extra_jars_s3_path
columns.comment: The path to one or more Java .jar files in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint.

columns.name: extra_python_libs_s3_path
columns.comment: The paths to one or more Python libraries in an Amazon S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint. Multiple values must be complete paths separated by a comma.

columns.name: failure_reason
columns.comment: The reason for a current failure in this DevEndpoint.

columns.name: glue_version
columns.comment: Glue version determines the versions of Apache Spark and Python that Glue supports.

columns.name: last_modified_timestamp
columns.comment: The point in time at which this DevEndpoint was last modified.

columns.name: last_update_status
columns.comment: The status of the last update.

columns.name: number_of_nodes
columns.comment: The number of Glue Data Processing Units (DPUs) allocated to this DevEndpoint.

columns.name: number_of_workers
columns.comment: The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated to the development endpoint.

columns.name: private_address
columns.comment: A private IP address to access the DevEndpoint within a VPC if the DevEndpoint is created within one.

columns.name: public_address
columns.comment: The public IP address used by this DevEndpoint. The PublicAddress field is present only when you create a non-virtual private cloud (VPC) DevEndpoint.

columns.name: public_key
columns.comment: The public key to be used by this DevEndpoint for authentication.

columns.name: role_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role used in this DevEndpoint.

columns.name: security_configuration
columns.comment: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this DevEndpoint.

columns.name: subnet_id
columns.comment: The subnet ID for this DevEndpoint.

columns.name: vpc_id
columns.comment: The ID of the virtual private cloud (VPC) used by this DevEndpoint.

columns.name: worker_type
columns.comment: The type of predefined worker that is allocated to the development endpoint. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

columns.name: yarn_endpoint_address
columns.comment: The YARN endpoint address used by this DevEndpoint.

columns.name: zeppelin_remote_spark_interpreter_port
columns.comment: The Apache Zeppelin port for the remote Apache Spark interpreter.

columns.name: public_keys
columns.comment: A list of public keys to be used by the DevEndpoints for authentication.

columns.name: security_group_ids
columns.comment: A list of security group identifiers used in this DevEndpoint.

columns.name: share_status
columns.comment: An indication of whether the query logging configuration is shared with other Amazon Web Services accounts, or was shared with the current account by another Amazon Web Services account. Sharing is configured through Resource Access Manager (RAM).

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for your private certificate authority (CA). The format is 12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789012.

columns.name: created_at
columns.comment: Date and time at which your private CA was created.

columns.name: failure_reason
columns.comment: Reason the request to create your private CA failed.

columns.name: key_storage_security_standard
columns.comment: Defines a cryptographic key management compliance standard used for handling CA keys. Default: FIPS_140_2_LEVEL_3_OR_HIGHER Note: Amazon Web Services Region ap-northeast-3 supports only FIPS_140_2_LEVEL_2_OR_HIGHER. You must explicitly specify this parameter and value when creating a CA in that Region. Specifying a different value (or no value) results in an InvalidArgsException with the message 'A certificate authority cannot be created in this region with the specified security standard.'

columns.name: last_state_change_at
columns.comment: Date and time at which your private CA was last updated.

columns.name: not_after
columns.comment: Date and time after which your private CA certificate is not valid.

columns.name: not_before
columns.comment: Date and time before which your private CA certificate is not valid.

columns.name: owner_account
columns.comment: The Amazon Web Services account ID that owns the certificate authority.

columns.name: restorable_until
columns.comment: The period during which a deleted CA can be restored. For more information, see the PermanentDeletionTimeInDays parameter of the DeleteCertificateAuthorityRequest action.

columns.name: serial
columns.comment: Serial number of your private CA.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: Status of your private CA.

columns.name: type
columns.comment: Type of your private CA.

columns.name: usage_mode
columns.comment: Specifies whether the CA issues general-purpose certificates that typically require a revocation mechanism, or short-lived certificates that may optionally omit revocation because they expire quickly. Short-lived certificate validity is limited to seven days. The default value is GENERAL_PURPOSE.

columns.name: certificate_authority_configuration
columns.comment: Your private CA configuration.

columns.name: revocation_configuration
columns.comment: Information about the Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) configuration or certificate revocation list (CRL) created and maintained by your private CA.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags associated with private certificate authority (CA).

columns.name: domain_name
columns.comment: The custom domain name as an API host name.

columns.name: certificate_arn
columns.comment: The reference to an AWS-managed certificate that will be used by edge-optimized endpoint for this domain name.

columns.name: certificate_name
columns.comment: The name of the certificate that will be used by edge-optimized endpoint for this domain name.

columns.name: certificate_upload_date
columns.comment: The timestamp when the certificate that was used by edge-optimized endpoint for this domain name was uploaded.

columns.name: distribution_domain_name
columns.comment: The domain name of the Amazon CloudFront distribution associated with this custom domain name for an edge-optimized endpoint.

columns.name: distribution_hosted_zone_id
columns.comment: The region-agnostic Amazon Route 53 Hosted Zone ID of the edge-optimized endpoint. The valid value is Z2FDTNDATAQYW2 for all the regions.

columns.name: domain_name_status
columns.comment: The status of the DomainName migration. The valid values are AVAILABLE and UPDATING. If the status is UPDATING, the domain cannot be modified further until the existing operation is complete.

columns.name: domain_name_status_message
columns.comment: An optional text message containing detailed information about status of the DomainName migration.

columns.name: ownership_verification_certificate_arn
columns.comment: The ARN of the public certificate issued by ACM to validate ownership of your custom domain. Only required when configuring mutual TLS and using an ACM imported or private CA certificate ARN as the regionalCertificateArn.

columns.name: regional_certificate_arn
columns.comment: The reference to an AWS-managed certificate that will be used for validating the regional domain name. AWS Certificate Manager is the only supported source.

columns.name: regional_certificate_name
columns.comment: The name of the certificate that will be used for validating the regional domain name.

columns.name: regional_domain_name
columns.comment: The domain name associated with the regional endpoint for this custom domain name. You set up this association by adding a DNS record that points the custom domain name to this regional domain name. The regional domain name is returned by API Gateway when you create a regional endpoint.

columns.name: regional_hosted_zone_id
columns.comment: The region-specific Amazon Route 53 Hosted Zone ID of the regional endpoint. For more information, see Set up a Regional Custom Domain Name and AWS Regions and Endpoints for API Gateway.

columns.name: security_policy
columns.comment: The Transport Layer Security (TLS) version + cipher suite for this DomainName. The valid values are TLS_1_0 and TLS_1_2.

columns.name: endpoint_configuration
columns.comment: The endpoint configuration of this DomainName showing the endpoint types of the domain name.

columns.name: mutual_tls_authentication
columns.comment: The mutual TLS authentication configuration for a custom domain name. If specified, API Gateway performs two-way authentication between the client and the server. Clients must present a trusted certificate to access your API.

columns.name: task_definition_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the task definition.

columns.name: cpu
columns.comment: The number of cpu units used by the task.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: The status of the task definition.

columns.name: execution_role_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the task execution role that grants the Amazon ECS container agent permission to make AWS API calls on your behalf.

columns.name: family
columns.comment: The name of a family that this task definition is registered to.

columns.name: ipc_mode
columns.comment: The IPC resource namespace to use for the containers in the task.

columns.name: memory
columns.comment: The amount (in MiB) of memory used by the task.

columns.name: network_mode
columns.comment: The Docker networking mode to use for the containers in the task.

columns.name: pid_mode
columns.comment: The process namespace to use for the containers in the task.

columns.name: revision
columns.comment: The revision of the task in a particular family.

columns.name: task_role_arn
columns.comment: The short name or full Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that grants containers in the task permission to call AWS APIs on your behalf.

columns.name: registered_at
columns.comment: The Unix timestamp for when the task definition was registered.

columns.name: registered_by
columns.comment: The principal that registered the task definition.

columns.name: container_definitions
columns.comment: A list of container definitions in JSON format that describe the different containers that make up your task.

columns.name: compatibilities
columns.comment: The launch type to use with your task.

columns.name: inference_accelerators
columns.comment: The Elastic Inference accelerator associated with the task.

columns.name: placement_constraints
columns.comment: An array of placement constraint objects to use for tasks.

columns.name: proxy_configuration
columns.comment: The configuration details for the App Mesh proxy.

columns.name: requires_attributes
columns.comment: The container instance attributes required by your task.

columns.name: requires_compatibilities
columns.comment: The launch type the task requires. If no value is specified, it will default to EC2. Valid values include EC2 and FARGATE.

columns.name: volumes
columns.comment: The list of volume definitions for the task.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags associated with task.

columns.name: service_namespace

columns.name: last_authenticated
columns.comment: The date and time when an authenticated entity most recently attempted to access the service. AWS does not report unauthenticated requests.

columns.name: last_authenticated_entity
columns.comment: The ARN of the authenticated entity (user or role) that last attempted to access the service. AWS does not report unauthenticated requests.

columns.name: last_authenticated_region
columns.comment: The Region from which the authenticated entity (user or role) last attempted to access the service. AWS does not report unauthenticated requests.

columns.name: total_authenticated_entities
columns.comment: The total number of authenticated principals (root user, IAM users, or IAM roles) that have attempted to access the service.

columns.name: tracked_actions_last_accessed
columns.comment: An array of objects that contains details about the most recent attempt to access a tracked action within the service.  Currently, only S3 supports action level tracking.

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the trail.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the trail.

columns.name: home_region
columns.comment: The region in which the trail was created.

columns.name: is_multi_region_trail
columns.comment: Specifies whether the trail exists only in one region or exists in all regions.

columns.name: log_file_validation_enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether log file validation is enabled, or not.

columns.name: is_logging
columns.comment: Specifies whether the CloudTrail is currently logging AWS API calls, or not.

columns.name: log_group_arn
columns.comment: Specifies an Amazon Resource Name (ARN), a unique identifier that represents the log group to which CloudTrail logs will be delivered.

columns.name: cloudwatch_logs_role_arn
columns.comment: Specifies the role for the CloudWatch Logs endpoint to assume to write to a user's log group.

columns.name: has_custom_event_selectors
columns.comment: Specifies whether the trail has custom event selectors, or not.

columns.name: has_insight_selectors
columns.comment: Specifies whether a trail has insight types specified in an InsightSelector list, or not.

columns.name: include_global_service_events
columns.comment: Specifies whether to include AWS API calls from AWS global services, or not.

columns.name: is_organization_trail
columns.comment: Specifies whether the trail is an organization trail, or not.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: Specifies the KMS key ID that encrypts the logs delivered by CloudTrail.

columns.name: s3_bucket_name
columns.comment: Name of the Amazon S3 bucket into which CloudTrail delivers your trail files.

columns.name: s3_key_prefix
columns.comment: Specifies the Amazon S3 key prefix that comes after the name of the bucket you have designated for log file delivery.

columns.name: sns_topic_arn
columns.comment: Specifies the ARN of the Amazon SNS topic that CloudTrail uses to send notifications when log files are delivered.

columns.name: latest_cloudwatch_logs_delivery_error
columns.comment: Displays any CloudWatch Logs error that CloudTrail encountered when attempting to deliver logs to CloudWatch Logs.

columns.name: latest_cloudwatch_logs_delivery_time
columns.comment: Displays the most recent date and time when CloudTrail delivered logs to CloudWatch Logs.

columns.name: latest_delivery_error
columns.comment: Displays any Amazon S3 error that CloudTrail encountered when attempting to deliver log files to the designated bucket.

columns.name: latest_delivery_time
columns.comment: Specifies the date and time that CloudTrail last delivered log files to an account's Amazon S3 bucket.

columns.name: latest_digest_delivery_error
columns.comment: Displays any Amazon S3 error that CloudTrail encountered when attempting to deliver a digest file to the designated bucket.

columns.name: latest_digest_delivery_time
columns.comment: Specifies the date and time that CloudTrail last delivered a digest file to an account's Amazon S3 bucket.

columns.name: latest_notification_error
columns.comment: Displays any Amazon SNS error that CloudTrail encountered when attempting to send a notification.

columns.name: latest_notification_time
columns.comment: Specifies the date and time of the most recent Amazon SNS notification that CloudTrail has written a new log file to an account's Amazon S3 bucket.

columns.name: start_logging_time
columns.comment: Specifies the most recent date and time when CloudTrail started recording API calls for an AWS account.

columns.name: stop_logging_time
columns.comment: Specifies the most recent date and time when CloudTrail stopped recording API calls for an AWS account.

columns.name: advanced_event_selectors
columns.comment: Describes the advanced event selectors that are configured for the trail.

columns.name: event_selectors
columns.comment: Describes the event selectors that are configured for the trail.

columns.name: insight_selectors
columns.comment: A JSON string that contains the insight types you want to log on a trail.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to the trail.

columns.comment: The number of threads per CPU core.

columns.comment: Indicates whether the instance is optimized for Amazon EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types.

columns.comment: Specifies whether enhanced networking with ENA is enabled.

columns.comment: Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

columns.comment: The public DNS name assigned to the instance. This name is not available until the instance enters the running state.

columns.name: lambda_function_timed_out_event_details

tables.name: aws.aws_vpc_flow_log_event
tables.comment: AWS VPC Flow Log events from CloudWatch Logs

columns.name: log_group_name
columns.comment: The name of the log group to which this event belongs.

columns.name: log_stream_name
columns.comment: The name of the log stream to which this event belongs.

columns.name: timestamp
columns.comment: The time when the event occurred.

columns.name: version
columns.comment: The VPC Flow Logs version. If you use the default format, the version is 2. If you use a custom format, the version is the highest version among the specified fields. For example, if you specify only fields from version 2, the version is 2. If you specify a mixture of fields from versions 2, 3, and 4, the version is 4.

columns.name: interface_account_id
columns.comment: The AWS account ID of the owner of the source network interface for which traffic is recorded. If the network interface is created by an AWS service, for example when creating a VPC endpoint or Network Load Balancer, the record may display unknown for this field.

columns.name: interface_id
columns.comment: The ID of the network interface for which the traffic is recorded.

columns.name: src_addr
columns.comment: The source address for incoming traffic, or the IPv4 or IPv6 address of the network interface for outgoing traffic on the network interface. The IPv4 address of the network interface is always its private IPv4 address. See also pkt-srcaddr.

columns.name: dst_addr
columns.comment: The destination address for outgoing traffic, or the IPv4 or IPv6 address of the network interface for incoming traffic on the network interface. The IPv4 address of the network interface is always its private IPv4 address. See also pkt-dstaddr.

columns.name: src_port
columns.comment: The source port of the traffic.

columns.name: dst_port
columns.comment: The destination port of the traffic.

columns.name: protocol
columns.comment: The IANA protocol number of the traffic. For more information, see Assigned Internet Protocol Numbers.

columns.name: packets
columns.comment: The number of packets transferred during the flow.

columns.name: bytes
columns.comment: The number of bytes transferred during the flow.

columns.name: start
columns.comment: The time when the first packet of the flow was received within the aggregation interval. This might be up to 60 seconds after the packet was transmitted or received on the network interface.

columns.name: end
columns.comment: The time when the last packet of the flow was received within the aggregation interval. This might be up to 60 seconds after the packet was transmitted or received on the network interface.

columns.name: action
columns.comment: The action that is associated with the traffic: ACCEPT  The recorded traffic was permitted by the security groups and network ACLs. REJECT  The recorded traffic was not permitted by the security groups or network ACLs.

columns.name: log_status
columns.comment: The logging status of the flow log: OK  Data is logging normally to the chosen destinations. NODATA  There was no network traffic to or from the network interface during the aggregation interval. SKIPDATA  Some flow log records were skipped during the aggregation interval. This may be because of an internal capacity constraint, or an internal error.

columns.name: event_id
columns.comment: The ID of the event.

columns.name: filter
columns.comment: Filter pattern for the search.

columns.name: ingestion_time
columns.comment: The time when the event was ingested.

columns.name: partition
columns.comment: The AWS partition in which the resource is located (aws, aws-cn, or aws-us-gov).

columns.name: region
columns.comment: The AWS Region in which the resource is located.

columns.name: account_id
columns.comment: The AWS Account ID in which the resource is located.

columns.name: og_account_id
columns.comment: The Platform Account ID in which the resource is located.

columns.name: og_resource_id

columns.name: id
columns.comment: The security findings provider-specific identifier for a finding.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the finding.

columns.name: company_name
columns.comment: The name of the company for the product that generated the finding.

columns.name: confidence
columns.comment: A finding's confidence. Confidence is defined as the likelihood that a finding accurately identifies the behavior or issue that it was intended to identify.

columns.name: created_at
columns.comment: Indicates when the security-findings provider created the potential security issue that a finding captured.

columns.name: compliance_status
columns.comment: The result of a compliance standards check.

columns.name: updated_at
columns.comment: Indicates when the security-findings provider last updated the finding record.

columns.name: criticality
columns.comment: The level of importance assigned to the resources associated with the finding.

columns.name: description
columns.comment: A finding's description.

columns.name: first_observed_at
columns.comment: Indicates when the security-findings provider first observed the potential security issue that a finding captured.

columns.name: generator_id
columns.comment: The identifier for the solution-specific component (a discrete unit of logic) that generated a finding.

columns.name: last_observed_at
columns.comment: Indicates when the security-findings provider most recently observed the potential security issue that a finding captured.

columns.name: product_arn
columns.comment: The ARN generated by Security Hub that uniquely identifies a product that generates findings.

columns.name: product_name
columns.comment: The name of the product that generated the finding.

columns.name: record_state
columns.comment: The record state of a finding.

columns.name: schema_version
columns.comment: The schema version that a finding is formatted for.

columns.name: source_url
columns.comment: A URL that links to a page about the current finding in the security-findings provider's solution.

columns.name: verification_state
columns.comment: Indicates the veracity of a finding.

columns.name: workflow_state
columns.comment: [DEPRECATED] This column has been deprecated and will be removed in a future release. The workflow state of a finding.

columns.name: workflow_status
columns.comment: The workflow status of a finding. Possible values are NEW, NOTIFIED, SUPPRESSED, RESOLVED.

columns.name: standards_control_arn
columns.comment: The ARN of the security standard control.

columns.name: action
columns.comment: Provides details about an action that affects or that was taken on a resource.

columns.name: compliance
columns.comment: This data type is exclusive to findings that are generated as the result of a check run against a specific rule in a supported security standard, such as CIS Amazon Web Services Foundations.

columns.name: finding_provider_fields
columns.comment: In a BatchImportFindings request, finding providers use FindingProviderFields to provide and update their own values for confidence, criticality, related findings, severity, and types.

columns.name: malware
columns.comment: A list of malware related to a finding.

columns.name: network
columns.comment: The details of network-related information about a finding.

columns.name: network_path
columns.comment: Provides information about a network path that is relevant to a finding. Each entry under NetworkPath represents a component of that path.

columns.name: note
columns.comment: A user-defined note added to a finding.

columns.name: patch_summary
columns.comment: Provides an overview of the patch compliance status for an instance against a selected compliance standard.

columns.name: process

columns.name: related_findings

columns.name: resources

columns.name: severity

columns.name: threat_intel_indicators
columns.comment: Threat intelligence details related to a finding.

columns.comment: A list of name/value string pairs associated with the finding.

columns.name: vulnerabilities

columns.comment: The account id where the affected resource lives.

columns.name: ip_protocol
columns.comment: The IP protocol name (tcp, udp, icmp, icmpv6) or number [see Protocol Numbers ](http://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/protocol-numbers.xhtml). Use -1 to specify all protocols. When authorizing security group rules, specifying -1 or a protocol number other than tcp, udp, icmp, or icmpv6 allows traffic on all ports, regardless of any port range specified. For tcp, udp, and icmp, a port range is specified. For icmpv6, the port range is optional. If port range is omitted, traffic for all types and codes is allowed.

columns.name: from_port
columns.comment: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP/ICMPv6 type number. A value of -1 indicates all ICMP/ICMPv6 types.

columns.name: to_port
columns.comment: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP/ICMPv6 code. A value of -1 indicates all ICMP/ICMPv6 codes.

columns.name: cidr_ip
columns.comment: The IPv4 CIDR range. It can be either a CIDR range or a source security group, not both. A single IPv4 address is denoted by /32 prefix length.

columns.name: cidr_ipv4
columns.comment: The IPv4 CIDR range.

columns.name: cidr_ipv6
columns.comment: The IPv6 CIDR range. It can be either a CIDR range or a source security group, not both. A single IPv6 address is denoted by /128 prefix length.

columns.comment: The ID of the security group that references this user ID group pair.

columns.comment: The ID of the referenced security group.

columns.name: pair_group_name
columns.comment: The name of the security group that references this user ID group pair.

columns.comment: The status of a VPC peering connection, if applicable.

columns.name: pair_user_id
columns.comment: The ID of an AWS account. For a referenced security group in another VPC, the account ID of the referenced security group is returned in the response. If the referenced security group is deleted, this value is not returned.

columns.name: referenced_user_id
columns.comment: The ID of an AWS account. For a referenced security group in another VPC, the account ID of the referenced security group is returned in the response. If the referenced security group is deleted, this value is not returned.

columns.name: pair_vpc_id
columns.comment: The ID of the VPC for the referenced security group, if applicable.

columns.name: referenced_vpc_id
columns.comment: The ID of the VPC for the referenced security group, if applicable.

columns.comment: The ID of the VPC peering connection, if applicable.

columns.name: referenced_vpc_peering_connection_id
columns.comment: The ID of the VPC peering connection, if applicable.

columns.name: prefix_list_id
columns.comment: The ID of the referenced prefix list.

columns.name: capacity_reservation_id
columns.comment: The ID of the capacity reservation.

columns.name: capacity_reservation_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the capacity reservation.

columns.name: instance_type
columns.comment: The type of instance for which the capacity reservation reserves capacity.

columns.name: state
columns.comment: The current state of the capacity reservation. A capacity reservation can be in one of the following states: 'active', 'expired', 'cancelled', 'pending', 'failed'.

columns.name: availability_zone
columns.comment: The availability zone in which the capacity is reserved.

columns.name: availability_zone_id
columns.comment: The availability zone ID of the capacity reservation.

columns.name: available_instance_count
columns.comment: The remaining capacity. Indicates the number of instances that can be launched in the capacity reservation.

columns.name: create_date
columns.comment: The date and time at which the capacity reservation was created.

columns.name: ebs_optimized
columns.comment: Indicates whether the capacity reservation supports EBS-optimized instances.

columns.name: end_date
columns.comment: The date and time at which the capacity reservation expires.

columns.name: end_date_type
columns.comment: Indicates the way in which the capacity reservation ends. A capacity reservation can have one of the following end types: 'unlimited', 'limited'.

columns.name: ephemeral_storage
columns.comment: Indicates whether the capacity reservation supports instances with temporary, block-level storage.

columns.name: instance_match_criteria
columns.comment: Indicates the type of instance launches that the capacity reservation accepts. The options include: 'open', 'targeted'.

columns.name: instance_platform
columns.comment: The type of operating system for which the capacity reservation reserves capacity.

columns.name: owner_id
columns.comment: The ID of the AWS account that owns the capacity reservation.

columns.name: start_date
columns.comment: The date and time at which the capacity reservation was started.

columns.name: tenancy
columns.comment: Indicates the tenancy of the capacity reservation. A capacity reservation can have one of the following tenancy settings: 'default', 'dedicated'.

columns.name: total_instance_count
columns.comment: The total number of instances for which the capacity reservation reserves capacity.

columns.name: capacity_allocations
columns.comment: Information about instance capacity usage.

columns.name: tag_src
columns.comment: Any tags assigned to the capacity reservation.
