columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the alarm.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the alarm.

columns.name: state_value
columns.comment: The state value for the alarm.

columns.name: actions_enabled
columns.comment: Indicates whether actions should be executed during any changes to the alarm state.

columns.name: alarm_configuration_updated_timestamp
columns.comment: The time stamp of the last update to the alarm configuration.

columns.name: alarm_description
columns.comment: The description of the alarm.

columns.name: comparison_operator
columns.comment: The arithmetic operation to use when comparing the specified statistic and threshold. The specified statistic value is used as the first operand.

columns.name: datapoints_to_alarm
columns.comment: The number of data points that must be breaching to trigger the alarm.

columns.name: evaluate_low_sample_count_percentile
columns.comment: Used only for alarms based on percentiles.

columns.name: evaluation_periods
columns.comment: The number of periods over which data is compared to the specified threshold.

columns.name: extended_statistic
columns.comment: The percentile statistic for the metric associated with the alarm. Specify a value between p0.0 and p100.

columns.name: metric_name
columns.comment: The name of the metric associated with the alarm, if this is an alarm based on a single metric.

columns.name: namespace
columns.comment: The namespace of the metric associated with the alarm.

columns.name: period
columns.comment: The period, in seconds, over which the statistic is applied.

columns.name: state_reason
columns.comment: An explanation for the alarm state, in text format.

columns.name: state_reason_data
columns.comment: An explanation for the alarm state, in JSON format.

columns.name: state_updated_timestamp
columns.comment: The time stamp of the last update to the alarm state.

columns.name: statistic
columns.comment: The statistic for the metric associated with the alarm, other than percentile.

columns.name: threshold
columns.comment: The value to compare with the specified statistic.

columns.name: threshold_metric_id
columns.comment: In an alarm based on an anomaly detection model, this is the ID of the ANOMALY_DETECTION_BAND function used as the threshold for the alarm.

columns.name: treat_missing_data
columns.comment: Sets how this alarm is to handle missing data points. If this parameter is omitted, the default behavior of missing is used.

columns.name: unit
columns.comment: The unit of the metric associated with the alarm.

columns.name: alarm_actions
columns.comment: The actions to execute when this alarm transitions to the ALARM state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

columns.name: dimensions
columns.comment: The dimensions for the metric associated with the alarm.

columns.name: insufficient_data_actions
columns.comment: The actions to execute when this alarm transitions to the INSUFFICIENT_DATA state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

columns.name: metrics
columns.comment: An array of MetricDataQuery structures, used in an alarm based on a metric math expression.

columns.name: ok_actions
columns.comment: The actions to execute when this alarm transitions to the OK state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: The list of tag keys and values associated with alarm.

columns.comment: The name associated with an Amazon EKS managed node group.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) associated with the managed node group.

columns.name: cluster_name
columns.comment: The name of the cluster that the managed node group resides in.

columns.name: created_at
columns.comment: The Unix epoch timestamp in seconds for when the managed node group was created.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: The current status of the managed node group.

columns.name: ami_type
columns.comment: The AMI type that was specified in the node group configuration.

columns.name: capacity_type
columns.comment: The capacity type of your managed node group.

columns.name: disk_size
columns.comment: The disk size in the node group configuration.

columns.name: modified_at
columns.comment: The Unix epoch timestamp in seconds for when the managed node group was last modified.

columns.name: node_role
columns.comment: The IAM role associated with your node group.

columns.name: release_version
columns.comment: If the node group was deployed using a launch template with a custom AMI, then this is the AMI ID that was specified in the launch template. For node groups that weren't deployed using a launch template, this is the version of the Amazon EKS optimized AMI that the node group was deployed with.

columns.name: version
columns.comment: The Kubernetes version of the managed node group.

columns.name: health
columns.comment: The health status of the node group.

columns.name: instance_types
columns.comment: The instance type that is associated with the node group. If the node group was deployed with a launch template, then this is null.

columns.name: labels
columns.comment: The Kubernetes labels applied to the nodes in the node group.

columns.name: launch_template
columns.comment: If a launch template was used to create the node group, then this is the launch template that was used.

columns.name: remote_access
columns.comment: The remote access configuration that is associated with the node group. If the node group was deployed with a launch template, then this is null.

columns.name: resources
columns.comment: The resources associated with the node group, such as Auto Scaling groups and security groups for remote access.

columns.name: scaling_config
columns.comment: The scaling configuration details for the Auto Scaling group that is associated with your node group.

columns.name: subnets
columns.comment: The subnets that were specified for the Auto Scaling group that is associated with your node group.

columns.name: tags
columns.comment: A map of tags for the resource.

columns.name: taints
columns.comment: The Kubernetes taints to be applied to the nodes in the node group when they are created.

columns.name: update_config
columns.comment: The node group update configuration.

columns.name: db_snapshot_identifier
columns.comment: The friendly name to identify the DB snapshot.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the DB snapshot.

columns.name: type
columns.comment: Provides the type of the DB snapshot.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: Specifies the status of this DB snapshot.

columns.name: create_time
columns.comment: Specifies when the snapshot was taken.

columns.name: allocated_storage
columns.comment: Specifies the allocated storage size in gibibytes(GiB).

columns.name: availability_zone
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the Availability Zone the DB instance was located in, at the time of the DB snapshot.

columns.name: db_instance_identifier
columns.comment: Specifies the DB instance identifier of the DB instance this DB snapshot was created from.

columns.name: dbi_resource_id
columns.comment: The identifier for the source DB instance, which can't be changed and which is unique to an AWS Region.

columns.name: encrypted
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB snapshot is encrypted, or not.

columns.name: engine
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the database engine.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: Specifies the version of the database engine.

columns.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether the mapping of AWS IAM accounts to database accounts is enabled, or not.

columns.name: instance_create_time
columns.comment: Specifies the time when the DB instance, from which the snapshot was taken, was created.

columns.name: iops
columns.comment: Specifies the Provisioned IOPS (I/O operations per second) value of the DB instance at the time of the snapshot.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: Specifies the AWS KMS key identifier for the encrypted DB snapshot.

columns.name: license_model
columns.comment: Specifies the License model information for the restored DB instance.

columns.name: master_user_name
columns.comment: Provides the master username for the DB snapshot.

columns.name: option_group_name
columns.comment: Provides the option group name for the DB snapshot.

columns.name: percent_progress
columns.comment: The percentage of the estimated data that has been transferred.

columns.name: port
columns.comment: Specifies the port that the database engine was listening on at the time of the snapshot.

columns.name: source_db_snapshot_identifier
columns.comment: The DB snapshot ARN that the DB snapshot was copied from.

columns.name: source_region
columns.comment: The AWS Region that the DB snapshot was created in or copied from.

columns.name: storage_type
columns.comment: Specifies the storage type associated with DB snapshot.

columns.name: tde_credential_arn
columns.comment: The ARN from the key store with which to associate the instance for TDE encryption.

columns.name: timezone
columns.comment: The time zone of the DB snapshot.

columns.name: vpc_id
columns.comment: Provides the VPC ID associated with the DB snapshot.

columns.name: db_snapshot_attributes
columns.comment: A list of DB snapshot attribute names and values for a manual DB snapshot.

columns.name: processor_features
columns.comment: The number of CPU cores and the number of threads per core for the DB instance class of the DB instance when the DB snapshot was created.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags attached to the DB snapshot.

tables.name: aws.aws_ec2_ami_shared
tables.comment: AWS EC2 AMI - All public, private, and shared AMIs

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the AMI that was provided during image creation.

columns.name: image_id
columns.comment: The ID of the AMI.

columns.name: state
columns.comment: The current state of the AMI. If the state is available, the image is successfully registered and can be used to launch an instance.

columns.name: image_type
columns.comment: The type of image.

columns.name: image_location
columns.comment: The location of the AMI.

columns.name: creation_date
columns.comment: The date and time when the image was created.

columns.name: architecture
columns.comment: The architecture of the image.

columns.name: description
columns.comment: The description of the AMI that was provided during image creation.

columns.name: ena_support
columns.comment: Specifies whether enhanced networking with ENA is enabled.

columns.name: hypervisor
columns.comment: The hypervisor type of the image.

columns.name: image_owner_alias
columns.comment: The AWS account alias (for example, amazon, self) or the AWS account ID of the AMI owner.

columns.name: imds_support
columns.comment: If v2.0, it indicates that IMDSv2 is specified in the AMI.

columns.name: kernel_id
columns.comment: The kernel associated with the image, if any. Only applicable for machine images.

columns.name: owner_id
columns.comment: The AWS account ID of the image owner.

columns.name: platform
columns.comment: This value is set to windows for Windows AMIs; otherwise, it is blank.

columns.name: platform_details
columns.comment: The platform details associated with the billing code of the AMI. For more information, see Obtaining Billing Information (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ami-billing-info.html) in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

columns.name: public
columns.comment: Indicates whether the image has public launch permissions. The value is true if this image has public launch permissions or false if it has only implicit and explicit launch permissions.

columns.name: ramdisk_id
columns.comment: The RAM disk associated with the image, if any. Only applicable for machine images.

columns.name: root_device_name
columns.comment: The device name of the root device volume (for example, /dev/sda1).

columns.name: root_device_type
columns.comment: The type of root device used by the AMI. The AMI can use an EBS volume or an instance store volume.

columns.name: sriov_net_support
columns.comment: Specifies whether enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface is enabled.

columns.name: usage_operation
columns.comment: The operation of the Amazon EC2 instance and the billing code that is associated with the AMI. For the list of UsageOperation codes, see Platform Details and [Usage Operation Billing Codes](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ami-billing-info.html#billing-info) in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

columns.name: virtualization_type

columns.comment: Indicates whether to opt in to or out of certificate transparency logging. Certificates that are not logged typically generate a browser error. Transparency makes it possible for you to detect SSL/TLS certificates that have been mistakenly or maliciously issued for your domain.

columns.comment: The time at which the certificate was requested. This value exists only when the certificate type is AMAZON_ISSUED

columns.comment: The algorithm that was used to sign the certificate

columns.name: extended_key_usages
columns.comment: Specify one or more ExtendedKeyUsage extension values.

columns.name: failure_reason
columns.comment: The reason the certificate request failed. This value exists only when the certificate status is FAILED

columns.comment: A list of ARNs for the AWS resources that are using the certificate. A certificate can be used by multiple AWS resources

columns.name: status
columns.comment: The status of the certificate

columns.name: key_algorithm
columns.comment: The algorithm that was used to generate the public-private key pair

columns.name: not_after
columns.comment: The time after which the certificate is not valid

columns.name: not_before
columns.comment: The time before which the certificate is not valid

columns.name: renewal_eligibility
columns.comment: Specifies whether the certificate is eligible for renewal.

columns.name: revocation_reason
columns.comment: The reason the certificate was revoked. This value exists only when the certificate status is REVOKED

columns.name: revoked_at
columns.comment: The time at which the certificate was revoked. This value exists only when the certificate status is REVOKED

columns.name: serial
columns.comment: The serial number of the certificate

columns.name: type
columns.comment: The source of the certificate. For certificates provided by ACM, this value is AMAZON_ISSUED.

columns.name: domain_validation_options
columns.comment: Contains information about the initial validation of each domain name that occurs as a result of the RequestCertificate request. This field exists only when the certificate type is AMAZON_ISSUED

columns.name: in_use_by
columns.comment: A list of ARNs for the AWS resources that are using the certificate

columns.name: subject_alternative_names
columns.comment: One or more domain names (subject alternative names) included in the certificate. This list contains the domain names that are bound to the public key that is contained in the certificate. The subject alternative names include the canonical domain name (CN) of the certificate and additional domain names that can be used to connect to the website

columns.comment: The date and time when the credential report was created, in ISO 8601 date-time format (http://www.iso.org/iso/iso8601).

columns.name: access_key_1_active
columns.comment: Does the user have an access key and is the access key's status Active.

columns.name: access_key_1_last_rotated
columns.comment: The date and time when the user's access key was created or last changed.

columns.name: access_key_1_last_used_date
columns.comment: The date and time when the user's access key was most recently used to sign an AWS API request. When an access key is used more than once in a 15-minute span, only the first use is recorded in this field.

columns.name: access_key_1_last_used_region
columns.comment: The AWS Region in which the access key was most recently used. When an access key is used more than once in a 15-minute span, only the first use is recorded in this field.

columns.name: access_key_1_last_used_service
columns.comment: The AWS service that was most recently accessed with the access key. The value in this field uses the service's namespacefor example, s3 for Amazon S3 and ec2 for Amazon EC2. When an access key is used more than once in a 15-minute span, only the first use is recorded in this field.

columns.name: access_key_2_active
columns.comment: Does the user have a second access key and is the access key's status Active.

columns.name: access_key_2_last_rotated
columns.comment: The date and time when the user's second access key was created or last changed.

columns.name: access_key_2_last_used_date
columns.comment: The date and time when the user's second access key was most recently used to sign an AWS API request. When an access key is used more than once in a 15-minute span, only the first use is recorded in this field.

columns.name: access_key_2_last_used_region
columns.comment: The AWS Region in which the user's second access key was most recently used. When an access key is used more than once in a 15-minute span, only the first use is recorded in this field.

columns.name: access_key_2_last_used_service
columns.comment: The AWS service that was most recently accessed with the user's second access key. The value in this field uses the service's namespacefor example, s3 for Amazon S3 and ec2 for Amazon EC2. When an access key is used more than once in a 15-minute span, only the first use is recorded in this field.

columns.comment: The date and time when the user's second signing certificate was created or last changed.

columns.name: mfa_active

columns.name: password_enabled
columns.comment: When the user has a password, this value is true. Otherwise it is false. The value for the AWS account root user is always false.

columns.name: password_last_changed
columns.comment: The date and time when the user's password was last set.

columns.name: password_last_used
columns.comment: The date and time when the AWS account root user or IAM user's password was last used to sign in to an AWS website.

columns.name: password_status
columns.comment: The status of an user password. Password status can be one of used, never_used and not_set.

columns.name: password_next_rotation
columns.comment: When the account has a password policy that requires password rotation, this field contains the date and time.

columns.name: cache_cluster_id
columns.comment: An unique identifier for ElastiCache cluster.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The ARN (Amazon Resource Name) of the cache cluster.

columns.name: cache_node_type
columns.comment: The name of the compute and memory capacity node type for the cluster.

columns.name: cache_cluster_status
columns.comment: The current state of this cluster, one of the following values: available, creating, deleted, deleting, incompatible-network, modifying, rebooting cluster nodes, restore-failed, or snapshotting.

columns.name: at_rest_encryption_enabled
columns.comment: A flag that enables encryption at-rest when set to true.

columns.name: auth_token_enabled
columns.comment: A flag that enables using an AuthToken (password) when issuing Redis commands.

columns.name: auto_minor_version_upgrade
columns.comment: This parameter is currently disabled.

columns.name: cache_cluster_create_time
columns.comment: The date and time when the cluster was created.

columns.name: cache_subnet_group_name
columns.comment: The name of the cache subnet group associated with the cluster.

columns.name: client_download_landing_page
columns.comment: The URL of the web page where you can download the latest ElastiCache client library.

columns.name: configuration_endpoint
columns.comment: Represents a Memcached cluster endpoint which can be used by an application to connect to any node in the cluster.

columns.name: engine
columns.comment: The name of the cache engine (memcached or redis) to be used for this cluster.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: The version of the cache engine that is used in this cluster.

columns.name: num_cache_nodes
columns.comment: The number of cache nodes in the cluster.

columns.name: preferred_availability_zone
columns.comment: The name of the Availability Zone in which the cluster is located or 'Multiple' if the cache nodes are located in different Availability Zones.

columns.name: preferred_maintenance_window
columns.comment: Specifies the weekly time range during which maintenance on the cluster is performed.

columns.name: replication_group_id
columns.comment: The replication group to which this cluster belongs.

columns.name: snapshot_retention_limit
columns.comment: The number of days for which ElastiCache retains automatic cluster snapshots before deleting them.

columns.name: snapshot_window
columns.comment: The daily time range (in UTC) during which ElastiCache begins taking a daily snapshot of your cluster.

columns.name: transit_encryption_enabled
columns.comment: A flag that enables in-transit encryption when set to true.

columns.name: auth_token_last_modified_date
columns.comment: The date the auth token was last modified.

columns.name: ip_discovery
columns.comment: The network type associated with the cluster, either ipv4 or ipv6.

columns.name: network_type
columns.comment: Must be either ipv4, ipv6, or dual_stack.

columns.name: preferred_outpost_arn
columns.comment: The outpost ARN in which the cache cluster is created.

columns.name: replication_group_log_delivery_enabled
columns.comment: A boolean value indicating whether log delivery is enabled for the replication group.

columns.name: transit_encryption_mode
columns.comment: A setting that allows you to migrate your clients to use in-transit encryption, with no downtime.

columns.name: cache_parameter_group
columns.comment: Status of the cache parameter group.

columns.name: notification_configuration
columns.comment: Describes a notification topic and its status.

columns.name: pending_modified_values
columns.comment: A group of settings that are applied to the cluster in the future, or that are currently being applied.

columns.name: security_groups
columns.comment: A list of VPC Security Groups associated with the cluster.

columns.name: cache_nodes
columns.comment: A list of cache nodes that are members of the cluster.

columns.name: cache_security_groups
columns.comment: A list of cache security group elements, composed of name and status sub-elements.

columns.name: log_delivery_configurations
columns.comment: Returns the destination, format, and type of the logs.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags associated with the cluster.

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the training job.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the training job.

columns.name: training_job_status
columns.comment: The status of the training job.

columns.name: auto_ml_job_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an AutoML job.

columns.name: billable_time_in_seconds
columns.comment: The billable time in seconds. Billable time refers to the absolute wall-clock time.

columns.name: creation_time
columns.comment: A timestamp that shows when the training job was created.

columns.name: enable_managed_spot_training
columns.comment: A Boolean indicating whether managed spot training is enabled or not.

columns.name: enable_network_isolation
columns.comment: Specifies enable network isolation for training jobs.

columns.name: enable_inter_container_traffic_encryption
columns.comment: To encrypt all communications between ML compute instances in distributed training, choose True.

columns.name: failure_reason
columns.comment: If the training job failed, the reason it failed.

columns.name: labeling_job_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SageMaker Ground Truth labeling job that created the transform or training job.

columns.name: last_modified_time
columns.comment: Timestamp when the training job was last modified.

columns.name: profiling_status
columns.comment: Profiling status of a training job.

columns.name: role_arn
columns.comment: The AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role configured for the training job.

columns.name: secondary_status
columns.comment: Provides detailed information about the state of the training job.

columns.name: training_end_time
columns.comment: A timestamp that shows when the training job ended.

columns.name: training_start_time
columns.comment: Indicates the time when the training job starts on training instances.

columns.name: training_time_in_seconds
columns.comment: The training time in seconds.

columns.name: tuning_job_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the associated hyperparameter tuning job if the training job was launched by a hyperparameter tuning job.

columns.name: algorithm_specification
columns.comment: Information about the algorithm used for training, and algorithm metadata.

columns.name: checkpoint_config
columns.comment: Contains information about the output location for managed spot training checkpoint data.

columns.name: debug_hook_config
columns.comment: Configuration information for the Debugger hook parameters, metric and tensor collections, and storage paths.

columns.name: debug_rule_configurations
columns.comment: Configuration information for Debugger rules for debugging output tensors.

columns.name: debug_rule_evaluation_statuses
columns.comment: Evaluation status of Debugger rules for debugging on a training job.

columns.name: environment
columns.comment: The environment variables to set in the Docker container.

columns.name: experiment_config
columns.comment: Associates a SageMaker job as a trial component with an experiment and trial.

columns.name: final_metric_data_list
columns.comment: A collection of MetricData objects that specify the names, values, and dates and times that the training algorithm emitted to Amazon CloudWatch.

columns.name: hyper_parameters
columns.comment: Algorithm-specific parameters.

columns.name: input_data_config
columns.comment: An array of Channel objects that describes each data input channel.

columns.name: model_artifacts
columns.comment: Information about the Amazon S3 location that is configured for storing model artifacts.

columns.name: output_data_config
columns.comment: The S3 path where model artifacts that you configured when creating the job are stored.

columns.name: profiler_config
columns.comment: Configuration information for Debugger system monitoring,framework profiling and storage paths.

columns.name: profiler_rule_configurations
columns.comment: Configuration information for Debugger rules for profiling system and framework metrics.

columns.name: profiler_rule_evaluation_statuses
columns.comment: Evaluation status of Debugger rules for profiling on a training job.

columns.name: resource_config
columns.comment: Resources, including ML compute instances and ML storage volumes, that are configured for model training.

columns.name: secondary_status_transitions
columns.comment: A history of all of the secondary statuses that the training job has transitioned through.

columns.name: stopping_condition
columns.comment: Specifies a limit to how long a model training job can run.

columns.name: tensor_board_output_config
columns.comment: Configuration of storage locations for the Debugger TensorBoard output data.

columns.name: vpc_config
columns.comment: A VpcConfig object that specifies the VPC that this training job has access to.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to the training job.

tables.name: aws.aws_cost_usage
tables.comment: AWS Cost Explorer - Cost and Usage

columns.name: dimension_1
columns.comment: Valid values are AZ, INSTANCE_TYPE, LINKED_ACCOUNT, OPERATION, PURCHASE_TYPE, SERVICE, USAGE_TYPE, PLATFORM, TENANCY, RECORD_TYPE, LEGAL_ENTITY_NAME, DEPLOYMENT_OPTION, DATABASE_ENGINE, CACHE_ENGINE, INSTANCE_TYPE_FAMILY, REGION, BILLING_ENTITY, RESERVATION_ID, SAVINGS_PLANS_TYPE, SAVINGS_PLAN_ARN, OPERATING_SYSTEM

columns.name: dimension_2
columns.comment: Valid values are AZ, INSTANCE_TYPE, LINKED_ACCOUNT, OPERATION, PURCHASE_TYPE, SERVICE, USAGE_TYPE, PLATFORM, TENANCY, RECORD_TYPE, LEGAL_ENTITY_NAME, DEPLOYMENT_OPTION, DATABASE_ENGINE, CACHE_ENGINE, INSTANCE_TYPE_FAMILY, REGION, BILLING_ENTITY, RESERVATION_ID, SAVINGS_PLANS_TYPE, SAVINGS_PLAN_ARN, OPERATING_SYSTEM

columns.name: period_start
columns.comment: Start timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: period_end
columns.comment: End timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: estimated
columns.comment: Whether the result is estimated.

columns.name: blended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the average cost of usage across the consolidated billing family. If you use the consolidated billing feature in AWS Organizations, you can view costs using blended rates.

columns.name: blended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for blended costs.

columns.name: unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: Unblended costs represent your usage costs on the day they are charged to you. In finance terms, they represent your costs on a cash basis of accounting.

columns.name: unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for unblended costs.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the unblended cost after discounts.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net unblended costs.

columns.name: amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the effective cost of the upfront and monthly reservation fees spread across the billing period. By default, Cost Explorer shows the fees for Reserved Instances as a spike on the day that you're charged, but if you choose to show costs as amortized costs, the costs are amortized over the billing period. This means that the costs are broken out into the effective daily rate. AWS estimates your amortized costs by combining your unblended costs with the amortized portion of your upfront and recurring reservation fees.

columns.name: amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for amortized costs.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric amortizes the upfront and monthly reservation fees while including discounts such as RI volume discounts.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net amortized costs.

columns.name: usage_quantity_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred. NOTE: If you return the UsageQuantity metric, the service aggregates all usage numbers without taking into account the units. For example, if you aggregate usageQuantity across all of Amazon EC2, the results aren't meaningful because Amazon EC2 compute hours and data transfer are measured in different units (for example, hours vs. GB).

columns.name: usage_quantity_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for usage quantity.

columns.name: normalized_usage_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred, in normalized units, for size-flexible RIs. The NormalizedUsageAmount is equal to UsageAmount multiplied by NormalizationFactor.

columns.name: normalized_usage_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for normalized usage.

tables.name: aws.aws_s3_account_settings
tables.comment: AWS S3 Account Block Public Access Settings

columns.name: block_public_acls
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should block public access control lists (ACLs) for this bucket and objects in this bucket

columns.name: block_public_policy
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should block public bucket policies for this bucket. If TRUE it causes Amazon S3 to reject calls to PUT Bucket policy if the specified bucket policy allows public access

columns.name: ignore_public_acls
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should ignore public ACLs for this bucket and objects in this bucket. Setting this element to TRUE causes Amazon S3 to ignore all public ACLs on this bucket and objects in this bucket

columns.name: restrict_public_buckets
columns.comment: Specifies whether Amazon S3 should restrict public bucket policies for this bucket. Setting this element to TRUE restricts access to this bucket to only AWS service principals and authorized users within this account if the bucket has a public policy

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the cluster.

columns.name: id
columns.comment: The unique identifier for the cluster.

columns.name: cluster_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name of the cluster.

columns.name: state
columns.comment: The current state of the cluster.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: The current status details about the cluster.

columns.name: auto_scaling_role
columns.comment: An IAM role for automatic scaling policies.

columns.name: auto_terminate
columns.comment: Specifies whether the cluster should terminate after completing all steps.

columns.name: custom_ami_id
columns.comment: Available only in Amazon EMR version 5.7.0 and later. The ID of a custom Amazon EBS-backed Linux AMI if the cluster uses a custom AMI.

columns.name: ebs_root_volume_size
columns.comment: The size of the Amazon EBS root device volume of the Linux AMI that is used for each EC2 instance, in GiB. Available in Amazon EMR version 4.x and later.

columns.name: instance_collection_type
columns.comment: The instance group configuration of the cluster.

columns.name: log_encryption_kms_key_id
columns.comment: The AWS KMS customer master key (CMK) used for encrypting log files. This attribute is only available with EMR version 5.30.0 and later, excluding EMR 6.0.0.

columns.name: log_uri
columns.comment: The path to the Amazon S3 location where logs for this cluster are stored.

columns.name: outpost_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Outpost where the cluster is launched.

columns.name: master_public_dns_name
columns.comment: The DNS name of the master node.

columns.name: normalized_instance_hours
columns.comment: An approximation of the cost of the cluster, represented in m1.small/hours.

columns.name: release_label
columns.comment: The Amazon EMR release label, which determines the version of open-source application packages installed on the cluster.

columns.name: repo_upgrade_on_boot
columns.comment: Applies only when CustomAmiID is used. Specifies the type of updates that are applied from the Amazon Linux AMI package repositories when an instance boots using the AMI.

columns.name: requested_ami_version
columns.comment: Applies only when CustomAmiID is used. Specifies the type of updates that are applied from the Amazon Linux AMI package repositories when an instance boots using the AMI.

columns.name: running_ami_version
columns.comment: The AMI version running on this cluster.

columns.name: scale_down_behavior
columns.comment: The way that individual Amazon EC2 instances terminate when an automatic scale-in activity occurs or an instance group is resized.

columns.name: security_configuration
columns.comment: The name of the security configuration applied to the cluster.

columns.name: service_role
columns.comment: The IAM role that will be assumed by the Amazon EMR service to access AWS resources on your behalf.

columns.name: step_concurrency_level
columns.comment: Specifies the number of steps that can be executed concurrently.

columns.name: termination_protected
columns.comment: Indicates whether Amazon EMR will lock the cluster to prevent the EC2 instances from being terminated by an API call or user intervention, or in the event of a cluster error.

columns.name: visible_to_all_users
columns.comment: Indicates whether the cluster is visible to all IAM users of the AWS account associated with the cluster.

columns.name: applications
columns.comment: The applications installed on this cluster.

columns.name: configurations
columns.comment: Applies only to Amazon EMR releases 4.x and later. The list of Configurations supplied to the EMR cluster.

columns.name: ec2_instance_attributes
columns.comment: Provides information about the EC2 instances in a cluster grouped by category.

columns.name: placement_groups
columns.comment: Placement group configured for an Amazon EMR cluster.

columns.name: kerberos_attributes
columns.comment: Attributes for Kerberos configuration when Kerberos authentication is enabled using a security configuration.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags associated with a cluster.

columns.comment: Specifies whether to crawl the entire dataset again or to crawl only folders that were added since the last crawler run. A value of CRAWL_EVERYTHING specifies crawling the entire dataset again. A value of CRAWL_NEW_FOLDERS_ONLY specifies crawling only folders that were added since the last crawler run. A value of CRAWL_EVENT_MODE specifies crawling only the changes identified by Amazon S3 events.

columns.comment: The policy that specifies update and delete behaviors for the crawler.

columns.name: queue_url
columns.comment: The URL of the Amazon SQS queue.

columns.name: queue_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon resource name (ARN) of the queue.

columns.name: fifo_queue
columns.comment: Returns true if the queue is FIFO.

columns.name: fifo_throughput_limit
columns.comment: Specifies whether the FIFO queue throughput quota applies to the entire queue or per message group.

columns.name: delay_seconds
columns.comment: The default delay on the queue in seconds.

columns.name: max_message_size
columns.comment: The limit of how many bytes a message can contain before Amazon SQS rejects it.

columns.name: message_retention_seconds
columns.comment: The length of time, in seconds, for which Amazon SQS retains a message.

columns.name: receive_wait_time_seconds
columns.comment: The length of time, in seconds, for which the ReceiveMessage action waits for a message to arrive.

columns.name: sqs_managed_sse_enabled
columns.comment: Returns true if the queue is using SSE-SQS encryption with SQS-owned encryption keys.

columns.name: visibility_timeout_seconds
columns.comment: The visibility timeout for the queue in seconds.

columns.name: policy
columns.comment: The resource IAM policy of the queue.

columns.name: policy_std
columns.comment: Contains the policy in a canonical form for easier searching.

columns.name: redrive_policy
columns.comment: The string that includes the parameters for the dead-letter queue functionality of the source queue as a JSON object.

columns.name: content_based_deduplication
columns.comment: Mentions whether content-based deduplication is enabled for the queue.

columns.name: deduplication_scope
columns.comment: Specifies whether message deduplication occurs at the message group or queue level.

columns.name: kms_master_key_id
columns.comment: the ID of an AWS-managed customer master key (CMK) for Amazon SQS or a custom CMK.

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The table name.

columns.name: catalog_id
columns.comment: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the table resides.

columns.name: create_time
columns.comment: The time when the table definition was created in the data catalog.

columns.name: description
columns.comment: A description of the table.

columns.name: created_by
columns.comment: The person or entity who created the table.

columns.name: database_name
columns.comment: The name of the database where the table metadata resides.

columns.name: is_registered_with_lake_formation
columns.comment: Indicates whether the table has been registered with lake formation.

columns.name: last_access_time
columns.comment: The last time that the table was accessed. This is usually taken from HDFS, and might not be reliable.

columns.name: last_analyzed_time
columns.comment: The last time that column statistics were computed for this table.

columns.name: owner
columns.comment: The owner of the table.

columns.name: retention
columns.comment: The retention time for this table.

columns.name: table_type
columns.comment: The type of this table (EXTERNAL_TABLE, VIRTUAL_VIEW, etc.).

columns.name: update_time
columns.comment: The last time that the table was updated.

columns.name: view_expanded_text
columns.comment: If the table is a view, the expanded text of the view otherwise null.

columns.name: view_original_text
columns.comment: If the table is a view, the original text of the view otherwise null.

columns.name: parameters
columns.comment: These key-value pairs define properties associated with the table.

columns.name: partition_keys
columns.comment: A list of columns by which the table is partitioned.

columns.name: storage_descriptor
columns.comment: A storage descriptor containing information about the physical storage of this table.

columns.name: target_table
columns.comment: A TableIdentifier structure that describes a target table for resource linking.

columns.name: lf_tags
columns.comment: LF-Tags assigned to the table by AWS Lake Formation.

columns.name: cluster_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the cluster.

columns.name: cluster_name
columns.comment: A user-generated string that you use to identify your cluster.

columns.name: active_services_count
columns.comment: The number of services that are running on the cluster in an ACTIVE state.

columns.name: pending_tasks_count
columns.comment: The number of tasks in the cluster that are in the PENDING state.

columns.name: registered_container_instances_count
columns.comment: The number of container instances registered into the cluster. This includes container instances in both ACTIVE and DRAINING status.

columns.name: running_tasks_count
columns.comment: The number of tasks in the cluster that are in the RUNNING state.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: The status of the cluster.

columns.name: attachments_status
columns.comment: The status of the capacity providers associated with the cluster.

columns.name: attachments
columns.comment: The resources attached to a cluster. When using a capacity provider with a cluster, the Auto Scaling plan that is created will be returned as a cluster attachment.

columns.name: capacity_providers
columns.comment: The capacity providers associated with the cluster.

columns.name: default_capacity_provider_strategy
columns.comment: The default capacity provider strategy for the cluster.

columns.name: settings
columns.comment: The settings for the cluster. This parameter indicates whether CloudWatch Container Insights is enabled or disabled for a cluster.

columns.name: statistics
columns.comment: Additional information about your clusters that are separated by launch type.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags attached to the cluster.

columns.comment: The name of the Availability Zone, Local Zone, or Wavelength Zone

columns.name: zone_id
columns.comment: The ID of the Availability Zone, Local Zone, or Wavelength Zone.

columns.name: zone_type
columns.comment: The type of zone. The valid values are availability-zone, local-zone, and wavelength-zone.

columns.name: opt_in_status
columns.comment: For Availability Zones, this parameter always has the value of opt-in-not-required. For Local Zones and Wavelength Zones, this parameter is the opt-in status. The possible values are opted-in, and not-opted-in.

columns.name: group_name
columns.comment: For Availability Zones, this parameter has the same value as the Region name. For Local Zones, the name of the associated group, for example us-west-2-lax-1. For Wavelength Zones, the name of the associated group, for example us-east-1-wl1-bos-wlz-1.

columns.name: region_name
columns.comment: The name of the Region.

columns.name: parent_zone_name
columns.comment: The name of the zone that handles some of the Local Zone or Wavelength Zone control plane operations, such as API calls.

columns.name: parent_zone_id
columns.comment: The ID of the zone that handles some of the Local Zone or Wavelength Zone control plane operations, such as API calls

columns.name: messages
columns.comment: Any messages about the Availability Zone, Local Zone, or Wavelength Zone.

columns.name: db_cluster_snapshot_identifier
columns.comment: The friendly name to identify the DB Cluster Snapshot.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the DB Cluster Snapshot.

columns.name: type
columns.comment: The type of the DB Cluster Snapshot.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: Specifies the status of this DB Cluster Snapshot.

columns.name: db_cluster_identifier
columns.comment: The friendly name to identify the DB Cluster, that the snapshot snapshot was created from.

columns.name: create_time
columns.comment: The time when the snapshot was taken.

columns.name: allocated_storage
columns.comment: Specifies the allocated storage size in gibibytes (GiB).

columns.name: cluster_create_time
columns.comment: Specifies the time when the DB cluster was created.

columns.name: engine
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the database engine.

columns.name: engine_version
columns.comment: Specifies the version of the database engine for this DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether mapping of AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) accounts to database accounts is enabled, or not.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: The AWS KMS key identifier for the AWS KMS customer master key (CMK).

columns.name: license_model
columns.comment: Provides the license model information for this DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: master_user_name
columns.comment: Provides the master username for the DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: percent_progress
columns.comment: Specifies the percentage of the estimated data that has been transferred.

columns.name: port
columns.comment: Specifies the port that the DB cluster was listening on at the time of the snapshot.

columns.name: source_db_cluster_snapshot_arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the source DB cluster snapshot, if the DB cluster snapshot was copied from a source DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: storage_encrypted
columns.comment: Specifies whether the DB cluster snapshot is encrypted, or not.

columns.name: vpc_id
columns.comment: Provides the VPC ID associated with the DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: availability_zones
columns.comment: A list of Availability Zones (AZs) where instances in the DB cluster snapshot can be restored.

columns.name: db_cluster_snapshot_attributes
columns.comment: A list of DB cluster snapshot attribute names and values for a manual DB cluster snapshot.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags attached to the DB Cluster Snapshot.

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the Maintenance Window.

columns.name: window_id
columns.comment: The ID of the Maintenance Window.

columns.name: enabled
columns.comment: Indicates whether the Maintenance Window is enabled.

columns.name: allow_unassociated_targets
columns.comment: Indicates whether targets must be registered with the Maintenance Window before tasks can be defined for those targets.

columns.name: description
columns.comment: A description of the Maintenance Window.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to the Maintenance Window

columns.name: duration
columns.comment: The duration of the Maintenance Window in hours.

columns.name: cutoff
columns.comment: The number of hours before the end of the Maintenance Window that Systems Manager stops scheduling new tasks for execution.

columns.name: schedule
columns.comment: The schedule of the Maintenance Window in the form of a cron or rate expression.

columns.name: schedule_offset
columns.comment: The number of days to wait to run a Maintenance Window after the scheduled CRON expression date and time.

columns.name: targets
columns.comment: The targets of Maintenance Window.

columns.name: tasks
columns.comment: The Tasks of Maintenance Window.

columns.name: created_date
columns.comment: The date the maintenance window was created.

columns.name: end_date
columns.comment: The date and time, in ISO-8601 Extended format, for when the maintenance window is scheduled to become inactive. The maintenance window will not run after this specified time.

columns.name: schedule_timezone
columns.comment: The schedule of the maintenance window in the form of a cron or rate expression.

columns.name: start_date
columns.comment: The date and time, in ISO-8601 Extended format, for when the maintenance window is scheduled to become active.

columns.name: modified_date
columns.comment: The date the Maintenance Window was last modified.

columns.name: next_execution_time
columns.comment: The next time the maintenance window will actually run, taking into account any specified times for the Maintenance Window to become active or inactive.

columns.name: snapshot_id
columns.comment: The ID of the snapshot. Each snapshot receives a unique identifier when it is created.

columns.name: arn
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) specifying the snapshot.

columns.name: state
columns.comment: The snapshot state.

columns.name: volume_size
columns.comment: The size of the volume, in GiB.

columns.name: volume_id
columns.comment: The ID of the volume that was used to create the snapshot. Snapshots created by the CopySnapshot action have an arbitrary volume ID that should not be used for any purpose.

columns.name: encrypted
columns.comment: Indicates whether the snapshot is encrypted.

columns.name: start_time
columns.comment: The time stamp when the snapshot was initiated.

columns.name: description
columns.comment: The description for the snapshot.

columns.name: kms_key_id
columns.comment: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) that was used to protect the volume encryption key for the parent volume.

columns.name: data_encryption_key_id
columns.comment: The data encryption key identifier for the snapshot. This value is a unique identifier that corresponds to the data encryption key that was used to encrypt the original volume or snapshot copy. Because data encryption keys are inherited by volumes created from snapshots, and vice versa, if snapshots share the same data encryption key identifier, then they belong to the same volume/snapshot lineage.

columns.name: progress
columns.comment: The progress of the snapshot, as a percentage.

columns.name: state_message
columns.comment: Encrypted Amazon EBS snapshots are copied asynchronously. If a snapshot copy operation fails this field displays error state details to help you diagnose why the error occurred.

columns.name: owner_alias
columns.comment: The AWS owner alias, from an Amazon-maintained list (amazon). This is not the user-configured AWS account alias set using the IAM console.

columns.name: owner_id
columns.comment: The AWS account ID of the EBS snapshot owner.

columns.name: create_volume_permissions
columns.comment: The users and groups that have the permissions for creating volumes from the snapshot.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags assigned to the snapshot.

tables.name: aws.aws_cost_by_record_type_monthly
tables.comment: AWS Cost Explorer - Cost by Record Type (Monthly)

columns.name: linked_account_id
columns.comment: The linked AWS Account ID.

columns.name: record_type
columns.comment: The different types of charges such as RI fees, usage, costs, tax refunds, and credits.

columns.name: period_start
columns.comment: Start timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: period_end
columns.comment: End timestamp for this cost metric.

columns.name: estimated
columns.comment: Whether the result is estimated.

columns.name: blended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the average cost of usage across the consolidated billing family. If you use the consolidated billing feature in AWS Organizations, you can view costs using blended rates.

columns.name: blended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for blended costs.

columns.name: unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: Unblended costs represent your usage costs on the day they are charged to you. In finance terms, they represent your costs on a cash basis of accounting.

columns.name: unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for unblended costs.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the unblended cost after discounts.

columns.name: net_unblended_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net unblended costs.

columns.name: amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric reflects the effective cost of the upfront and monthly reservation fees spread across the billing period. By default, Cost Explorer shows the fees for Reserved Instances as a spike on the day that you're charged, but if you choose to show costs as amortized costs, the costs are amortized over the billing period. This means that the costs are broken out into the effective daily rate. AWS estimates your amortized costs by combining your unblended costs with the amortized portion of your upfront and recurring reservation fees.

columns.name: amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for amortized costs.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_amount
columns.comment: This cost metric amortizes the upfront and monthly reservation fees while including discounts such as RI volume discounts.

columns.name: net_amortized_cost_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for net amortized costs.

columns.name: usage_quantity_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred. NOTE: If you return the UsageQuantity metric, the service aggregates all usage numbers without taking into account the units. For example, if you aggregate usageQuantity across all of Amazon EC2, the results aren't meaningful because Amazon EC2 compute hours and data transfer are measured in different units (for example, hours vs. GB).

columns.name: usage_quantity_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for usage quantity.

columns.name: normalized_usage_amount
columns.comment: The amount of usage that you incurred, in normalized units, for size-flexible RIs. The NormalizedUsageAmount is equal to UsageAmount multiplied by NormalizationFactor.

columns.name: normalized_usage_unit
columns.comment: Unit type for normalized usage.

columns.comment: Unique identifier of the key.

columns.comment: ARN of the key.

columns.name: key_manager
columns.comment: The manager of the CMK. CMKs in your AWS account are either customer managed or AWS managed.

columns.name: creation_date
columns.comment: The date and time when the CMK was created.

columns.name: aws_account_id
columns.comment: The twelve-digit account ID of the AWS account that owns the CMK.

columns.name: enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether the CMK is enabled. When KeyState is Enabled this value is true, otherwise it is false.

columns.name: customer_master_key_spec
columns.comment: Describes the type of key material in the CMK.

columns.name: description
columns.comment: The description of the CMK.

columns.name: deletion_date
columns.comment: The date and time after which AWS KMS deletes the CMK.

columns.name: key_state
columns.comment: The current status of the CMK. For more information about how key state affects the use of a CMK, see [Key state: Effect on your CMK](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/kms/latest/developerguide/key-state.html).

columns.name: key_usage
columns.comment: The [cryptographic operations](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/kms/latest/developerguide/concepts.html#cryptographic-operations) for which you can use the CMK.

columns.name: origin
columns.comment: The source of the CMK's key material. When this value is AWS_KMS, AWS KMS created the key material. When this value is EXTERNAL, the key material was imported from your existing key management infrastructure or the CMK lacks key material. When this value is AWS_CLOUDHSM, the key material was created in the AWS CloudHSM cluster associated with a custom key store.

columns.name: valid_to
columns.comment: The time at which the imported key material expires.

columns.name: aliases
columns.comment: A list of aliases for the key.

columns.name: key_rotation_enabled
columns.comment: A Boolean value that specifies whether key rotation is enabled.

columns.name: policy
columns.comment: A key policy document in JSON format.

columns.name: policy_std
columns.comment: Contains the policy in a canonical form for easier searching.

columns.name: tags_src
columns.comment: A list of tags attached to key.

columns.comment: Specifies the size of the content returned.

columns.comment: Indicates content language specified for the blob.

columns.comment: Describes cause of fatal or non-fatal copy operation failure.

columns.name: lease_status
columns.comment: Specifies the lease status of the blob.

columns.comment: Indicate if the append blob is sealed or not.

columns.comment: Specifies an unique ID for VM, which is a 128-bits identifier that is encoded and stored in all Azure IaaS VMs SMBIOS and can be read using platform BIOS commands.

columns.name: size
columns.comment: Specifies the size of the virtual machine.

columns.name: admin_user_name
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the administrator account.

columns.name: allow_extension_operations
columns.comment: Specifies whether extension operations should be allowed on the virtual machine.

columns.name: availability_set_id
columns.comment: Specifies the ID of the availability set.

columns.name: billing_profile_max_price
columns.comment: Specifies the maximum price you are willing to pay for a Azure Spot VM/VMSS.

columns.name: boot_diagnostics_enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether boot diagnostics should be enabled on the Virtual Machine, or not.

columns.name: boot_diagnostics_storage_uri
columns.comment: Contains the Uri of the storage account to use for placing the console output and screenshot.

columns.name: computer_name
columns.comment: Specifies the host OS name of the virtual machine.

columns.name: disable_password_authentication
columns.comment: Specifies whether password authentication should be disabled.

columns.name: enable_automatic_updates
columns.comment: Indicates whether automatic updates is enabled for the windows virtual machine.

columns.name: eviction_policy
columns.comment: Specifies the eviction policy for the Azure Spot virtual machine and Azure Spot scale set.

columns.name: image_exact_version
columns.comment: Specifies in decimal numbers, the version of platform image or marketplace image used to create the virtual machine.

columns.name: image_id
columns.comment: Specifies the ID of the image to use.

columns.name: image_offer
columns.comment: Specifies the offer of the platform image or marketplace image used to create the virtual machine.

columns.name: image_publisher
columns.comment: Specifies the publisher of the image to use.

columns.name: image_sku
columns.comment: Specifies the sku of the image to use.

columns.name: image_version
columns.comment: Specifies the version of the platform image or marketplace image used to create the virtual machine.

columns.name: managed_disk_id
columns.comment: Specifies the ID of the managed disk used by the virtual machine.

columns.name: os_disk_caching
columns.comment: Specifies the caching requirements of the operating system disk used by the virtual machine.

columns.name: os_disk_create_option
columns.comment: Specifies how the virtual machine should be created.

columns.name: os_disk_name
columns.comment: Specifies the name of the operating system disk used by the virtual machine.

columns.name: os_disk_vhd_uri
columns.comment: Specifies the virtual hard disk's uri.

columns.comment: The Operating System running on the virtual machine.

columns.name: os_version
columns.comment: The version of Operating System running on the virtual machine.

columns.name: os_type
columns.comment: Specifies the type of the OS that is included in the disk if creating a VM from user-image or a specialized VHD.

columns.name: priority
columns.comment: Specifies the priority for the virtual machine.

columns.name: provision_vm_agent
columns.comment: Specifies whether virtual machine agent should be provisioned on the virtual machine for linux configuration.

columns.name: provision_vm_agent_windows
columns.comment: Specifies whether virtual machine agent should be provisioned on the virtual machine for windows configuration.

columns.name: require_guest_provision_signal
columns.comment: Specifies whether the guest provision signal is required to infer provision success of the virtual machine.

columns.name: ultra_ssd_enabled
columns.comment: Specifies whether managed disks with storage account type UltraSSD_LRS can be added to a virtual machine or virtual machine scale set, or not.

columns.name: time_zone
columns.comment: Specifies the time zone of the virtual machine.

columns.name: additional_unattend_content
columns.comment: Specifies additional base-64 encoded XML formatted information that can be included in the Unattend.xml file, which is used by windows setup.

columns.name: data_disks
columns.comment: A list of parameters that are used to add a data disk to a virtual machine.

columns.name: linux_configuration_ssh_public_keys
columns.comment: A list of ssh key configuration for a Linux OS

columns.name: network_interfaces
columns.comment: A list of resource Ids for the network interfaces associated with the virtual machine.

tables.name: azure.azure_app_service_web_app_slot
tables.comment: Azure App Service Web App Slot

columns.name: name
columns.comment: Resource Name.

columns.name: app_name
columns.comment: The name of the application.

columns.name: id
columns.comment: Resource ID of the app slot.

columns.name: kind
columns.comment: Contains the kind of the resource.

columns.name: state
columns.comment: Current state of the app.

columns.name: type
columns.comment: Resource type.

columns.name: last_modified_time_utc
columns.comment: Last time the app was modified, in UTC.

columns.name: repository_site_name
columns.comment: Name of the repository site.

columns.name: usage_state
columns.comment: State indicating whether the app has exceeded its quota usage. Read-only. Possible values include: 'UsageStateNormal', 'UsageStateExceeded'.

columns.name: enabled
columns.comment: Indicates wheather the app is enabled.

columns.name: availability_state
columns.comment: Management information availability state for the app. Possible values include: 'Normal', 'Limited', 'DisasterRecoveryMode'.

columns.name: server_farm_id
columns.comment: Resource ID of the associated App Service plan, formatted as: '/subscriptions/{subscriptionID}/resourceGroups/{groupName}/providers/Microsoft.Web/serverfarms/{appServicePlanName}'.

columns.name: reserved
columns.comment: True if reserved; otherwise, false.

columns.name: is_xenon
columns.comment: Obsolete: Hyper-V sandbox.

columns.name: hyper_v
columns.comment: Hyper-V sandbox.

columns.name: scm_site_also_stopped
columns.comment: True to stop SCM (KUDU) site when the app is stopped; otherwise, false. The default is false.

columns.name: target_swap_slot
columns.comment: Specifies which deployment slot this app will swap into.

columns.name: client_affinity_enabled
columns.comment: True to enable client affinity; false to stop sending session affinity cookies, which route client requests in the same session to the same instance. Default is true.

columns.name: client_cert_mode
columns.comment: This composes with ClientCertEnabled setting. ClientCertEnabled: false means ClientCert is ignored. ClientCertEnabled: true and ClientCertMode: Required means ClientCert is required.ClientCertEnabled: true and ClientCertMode: Optional means ClientCert is optional or accepted. Possible values include: 'Required', 'Optional'.

columns.name: client_cert_exclusion_paths
columns.comment: Client certificate authentication comma-separated exclusion paths.

columns.name: host_names_disabled
columns.comment: True to disable the public hostnames of the app; otherwise, false. If true, the app is only accessible via API management process.

columns.name: custom_domain_verification_id
columns.comment: Unique identifier that verifies the custom domains assigned to the app. The customer will add this ID to a text record for verification.

columns.name: outbound_ip_addresses
columns.comment: List of IP addresses that the app uses for outbound connections (e.g. database access). Includes VIPs from tenants that site can be hosted with current settings.

columns.name: possible_outbound_ip_addresses
columns.comment: List of IP addresses that the app uses for outbound connections (e.g. database access). Includes VIPs from all tenants except dataComponent.

columns.name: container_size
columns.comment: Size of the function container.

columns.name: suspended_till
columns.comment: App suspended till in case memory-time quota is exceeded.

columns.name: is_default_container
columns.comment: True if the app is a default container; otherwise, false.

columns.name: default_host_name
columns.comment: Default hostname of the app.

columns.name: https_only
columns.comment: Configures a web site to accept only https requests.

columns.name: redundancy_mode
columns.comment: Site redundancy mode. Possible values include: 'RedundancyModeNone', 'RedundancyModeManual', 'RedundancyModeFailover', 'RedundancyModeActiveActive', 'RedundancyModeGeoRedundant'.

columns.name: identity
columns.comment: Managed service identity.

columns.name: host_names
columns.comment: Hostnames associated with the app.

columns.name: enabled_host_names
columns.comment: Enabled hostnames for the app. Hostnames need to be assigned (see HostNames) AND enabled. Otherwise, the app is not served on those hostnames.

columns.name: host_name_ssl_states
columns.comment: Hostname SSL states are used to manage the SSL bindings for app's hostnames.

columns.name: site_config
columns.comment: Configuration of the app.

columns.name: traffic_manager_host_names
columns.comment: Azure Traffic Manager hostnames associated with the app.

columns.name: hosting_environment_profile
columns.comment: App Service Environment to use for the app.

columns.name: slot_swap_status
columns.comment: Status of the last deployment slot swap operation.

columns.name: site_config_resource
columns.comment: Configuration of an app, such as platform version and bitness, default documents, virtual applications, Always On, etc.

columns.comment: A state of a server that is visible to user. Possible values include: 'ServerStateReady', 'ServerStateDropping', 'ServerStateDisabled', 'ServerStateInaccessible'.

columns.comment: Specifies the version of the server.

columns.name: location

columns.comment: Specifies the earliest restore point creation time.

columns.comment: Indicates whether Geo-redundant is enabled, or not for server backup.

columns.name: infrastructure_encryption
columns.comment: Status showing whether the server enabled infrastructure encryption. Possible values include: 'InfrastructureEncryptionEnabled', 'InfrastructureEncryptionDisabled'.

columns.name: master_server_id
columns.comment: The master server id of a replica server.

columns.comment: Enforce a minimal Tls version for the server. Possible values include: 'TLS10', 'TLS11', 'TLS12', 'TLSEnforcementDisabled'.

columns.name: public_network_access
columns.comment: Indicates whether or not public network access is allowed for this server. Value is optional but if passed in, must be 'Enabled' or 'Disabled'. Possible values include: 'PublicNetworkAccessEnumEnabled', 'PublicNetworkAccessEnumDisabled'.

columns.name: sku_tier

columns.name: ssl_enforcement

columns.name: storage_auto_grow

columns.comment: Indicates max storage allowed for a server.

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the resource that is unique within the set of inbound NAT rules used by the load balancer. This name can be used to access the resource.

columns.name: id
columns.comment: The resource ID.

columns.name: load_balancer_name
columns.comment: The friendly name that identifies the load balancer.

columns.name: provisioning_state
columns.comment: The provisioning state of the inbound NAT rule resource.

columns.name: type
columns.comment: Type of the resource.

columns.name: etag
columns.comment: A unique read-only string that changes whenever the resource is updated.

columns.name: backend_port
columns.comment: The port used for the internal endpoint. Acceptable values range from 1 to 65535.

columns.name: enable_floating_ip
columns.comment: Configures a virtual machine's endpoint for the floating IP capability required to configure a SQL AlwaysOn Availability Group. This setting is required when using the SQL AlwaysOn Availability Groups in SQL server. This setting can't be changed after you create the endpoint.

columns.name: frontend_port
columns.comment: The port for the external endpoint. Port numbers for each rule must be unique within the Load Balancer. Acceptable values range from 1 to 65534.

columns.name: enable_tcp_reset
columns.comment: Receive bidirectional TCP Reset on TCP flow idle timeout or unexpected connection termination. This element is only used when the protocol is set to TCP.

columns.name: idle_timeout_in_minutes
columns.comment: The timeout for the TCP idle connection. The value can be set between 4 and 30 minutes. The default value is 4 minutes. This element is only used when the protocol is set to TCP.

columns.name: protocol
columns.comment: The reference to the transport protocol used by the load balancing rule. Possible values include: 'TransportProtocolUDP', 'TransportProtocolTCP', 'TransportProtocolAll'.

columns.name: backend_ip_configuration
columns.comment: A reference to a private IP address defined on a network interface of a VM. Traffic sent to the frontend port of each of the frontend IP configurations is forwarded to the backend IP.

columns.name: frontend_ip_configuration
columns.comment: A reference to frontend IP addresses.

columns.name: active_active
columns.comment: Indicates whether virtual network gateway configured with active-active mode, or not. If true, each Azure gateway instance will have a unique public IP address, and each will establish an IPsec/IKE S2S VPN tunnel to your on-premises VPN device specified in your local network gateway and connection.

columns.comment: Indicates whether BGP is enabled for this virtual network gateway, or not.

columns.name: enable_dns_forwarding

columns.comment: Indicates whether private IP needs to be enabled on this gateway for connections or not.

columns.comment: An unique read-only string that changes whenever the resource is updated.

columns.name: gateway_default_site
columns.comment: The reference to the LocalNetworkGateway resource, which represents local network site having default routes. Assign Null value in case of removing existing default site setting.

columns.name: inbound_dns_forwarding_endpoint
columns.comment: The IP address allocated by the gateway to which dns requests can be sent.

columns.comment: Virtual network gateway's BGP speaker settings.

columns.name: ip_configurations

columns.comment: The state of the last provisioning operation performed on the search service.

columns.name: status
columns.comment: The status of the search service. Possible values include: 'running', deleting', 'provisioning', 'degraded', 'disabled', 'error' etc.

columns.name: status_details
columns.comment: The details of the search service status.

columns.name: type
columns.comment: The type of the resource.

columns.name: hosting_mode
columns.comment: Applicable only for the standard3 SKU. You can set this property to enable up to 3 high density partitions that allow up to 1000 indexes, which is much higher than the maximum indexes allowed for any other SKU. For the standard3 SKU, the value is either 'default' or 'highDensity'. For all other SKUs, this value must be 'default'. Possible values include: 'Default', 'HighDensity'.

columns.name: partition_count
columns.comment: The number of partitions in the search service; if specified, it can be 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, or 12. Values greater than 1 are only valid for standard SKUs. For 'standard3' services with hostingMode set to 'highDensity', the allowed values are between 1 and 3.

columns.name: public_network_access
columns.comment: This value can be set to 'enabled' to avoid breaking changes on existing customer resources and templates. If set to 'disabled', traffic over public interface is not allowed, and private endpoint connections would be the exclusive access method. Possible values include: 'Enabled', 'Disabled'.

columns.name: replica_count
columns.comment: The number of replicas in the search service. If specified, it must be a value between 1 and 12 inclusive for standard SKUs or between 1 and 3 inclusive for basic SKU.

columns.name: sku_name
columns.comment: The SKU of the Search Service, which determines price tier and capacity limits. This property is required when creating a new search service.

columns.name: diagnostic_settings
columns.comment: A list of active diagnostic settings for the search service.

columns.name: identity
columns.comment: The identity of the resource.

columns.name: network_rule_set
columns.comment: Network specific rules that determine how the azure cognitive search service may be reached.

columns.name: private_endpoint_connections
columns.comment: The list of private endpoint connections to the azure cognitive search service.

columns.name: shared_private_link_resources
columns.comment: The list of shared private link resources managed by the azure cognitive search service.

columns.name: name
columns.comment: The name of the resource that is unique within the set of probes used by the load balancer. This name can be used to access the resource.

columns.name: id
columns.comment: The resource ID.

columns.name: load_balancer_name
columns.comment: The friendly name that identifies the load balancer.

columns.name: provisioning_state
columns.comment: The provisioning state of the probe resource. Possible values include: 'Succeeded', 'Updating', 'Deleting', 'Failed'.

columns.name: type
columns.comment: Type of the resource.

columns.name: etag
columns.comment: A unique read-only string that changes whenever the resource is updated.

columns.name: interval_in_seconds
columns.comment: The interval, in seconds, for how frequently to probe the endpoint for health status. Typically, the interval is slightly less than half the allocated timeout period (in seconds) which allows two full probes before taking the instance out of rotation. The default value is 15, the minimum value is 5.

columns.name: number_of_probes
columns.comment: The number of probes where if no response, will result in stopping further traffic from being delivered to the endpoint. This values allows endpoints to be taken out of rotation faster or slower than the typical times used in Azure.

columns.name: port
columns.comment: The port for communicating the probe. Possible values range from 1 to 65535, inclusive.

columns.name: protocol
columns.comment: The protocol of the end point. If 'Tcp' is specified, a received ACK is required for the probe to be successful. If 'Http' or 'Https' is specified, a 200 OK response from the specifies URI is required for the probe to be successful. Possible values include: 'HTTP', 'TCP', 'HTTPS'.

columns.name: request_path
columns.comment: The URI used for requesting health status from the VM. Path is required if a protocol is set to http. Otherwise, it is not allowed. There is no default value.

columns.name: load_balancing_rules
columns.comment: The load balancer rules that use this probe.

columns.comment: The provisioning state of the cluster resource. Possible values include: 'Updating', 'Succeeded', 'Failed', 'Canceled'.

columns.name: type
columns.comment: Azure resource type.

columns.name: cluster_code_version
columns.comment: The service fabric runtime version of the cluster. This property can only by set the user when **upgradeMode** is set to 'Manual'.

columns.name: cluster_endpoint
columns.comment: The azure resource provider endpoint. A system service in the cluster connects to this  endpoint.

columns.name: cluster_id
columns.comment: A service generated unique identifier for the cluster resource.

columns.name: cluster_state
columns.comment: The current state of the cluster. Possible values include: 'WaitingForNodes', 'Deploying', 'BaselineUpgrade', 'UpdatingUserConfiguration', 'UpdatingUserCertificate', 'UpdatingInfrastructure', 'EnforcingClusterVersion', 'UpgradeServiceUnreachable', 'AutoScale', 'Ready'.

columns.name: event_store_service_enabled
columns.comment: Indicates if the event store service is enabled.

columns.name: etag
columns.comment: Azure resource etag.

columns.name: management_endpoint
columns.comment: The http management endpoint of the cluster.

columns.name: reliability_level
columns.comment: The reliability level sets the replica set size of system services. Possible values include: 'None', 'Bronze', 'Silver', 'Gold', 'Platinum'.

columns.name: upgrade_mode
columns.comment: The upgrade mode of the cluster when new service fabric runtime version is available. Possible values include: 'Automatic', 'Manual'.

columns.name: vm_image
columns.comment: The VM image VMSS has been configured with. Generic names such as Windows or Linux can be used.

columns.name: add_on_features
columns.comment: The list of add-on features to enable in the cluster.

columns.name: available_cluster_versions
columns.comment: The service fabric runtime versions available for this cluster.

columns.name: azure_active_directory
columns.comment: The azure active directory authentication settings of the cluster.

columns.name: certificate
columns.comment: The certificate to use for securing the cluster. The certificate provided will be used for node to node security within the cluster, SSL certificate for cluster management endpoint and default admin client.

columns.name: certificate_common_names
columns.comment: Describes a list of server certificates referenced by common name that are used to secure the cluster.

columns.name: client_certificate_common_names
columns.comment: The list of client certificates referenced by common name that are allowed to manage the cluster.

columns.name: client_certificate_thumbprints
columns.comment: The list of client certificates referenced by thumbprint that are allowed to manage the cluster.

columns.name: diagnostics_storage_account_config
columns.comment: The storage account information for storing service fabric diagnostic logs.

columns.name: fabric_settings
columns.comment: The list of custom fabric settings to configure the cluster.

columns.name: node_types
columns.comment: The list of node types in the cluster.

columns.name: reverse_proxy_certificate
columns.comment: The server certificate used by reverse proxy.

columns.name: reverse_proxy_certificate_common_names
columns.comment: Describes a list of server certificates referenced by common name that are used to secure the cluster.

columns.name: upgrade_description
columns.comment: The policy to use when upgrading the cluster.
